Mr. L. D. O'Leary
Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

I have visited the Indians of Michibicoton a few days ago, and I was very sorry to see over twenty children in age of frequenting the school, obliged to stay home ill, because the school is closed for a great many years. The Indians asked me, if I could not do anything to obtain from the Department the reopening of the school, to give their children a
a chance of learning something. Therefore having found out by myself that there were then present in the vicinity 22 Indian children, a few more being absent with their parents, I write you to say that you know the miserable state of these poor children without any education, when the Department often opens schools for a smaller number of children.

Now besides the Indian children about ten or twelve white children would attend the school regularly if it was opened. I hope Mr. Secretary that you will do all in your power to give a school to these poor boys who, it seems to me, have a right to an education just as well as the others.
The school building is still good but the furniture are wanting. Please do your best to obtain from the Department the reopening of that school and obliged.

Your humble servant,

L. Rogers

Successor to Father Specht in these missions.
Ottawa, 10th October, 1896.

Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, informing the Department of the number of children of school age at Michipicoten, and urging that the school be re-opened at that point.

In reply I have to say that even if, in view of your representations, it should be found advisable to open a school again, this cannot be done this year, as no provision has been made by Parliament for the salary of the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Mr. J. D. McLean
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

In your latest letter Oct. 18th 1878 you tell me that Michibicon school could not be open then, as no provision had been made by Parliament for the salary of the teacher.

Now I am just coming from Michibicon, the Indians asked me if they could hope to have the school open soon, I told them that I would write again about it as soon as I would come to Fort William.

Did I tell you in my letter of Oct. 8th October last, about 20 indian children are in age of frequenting school, and
we obliged to stay idle at home because we have no teacher given them.

If the Department consents to reopen the school as I hope, that though he will do so, Miss Officer Barker well known to the Department would be willing to teach there from the first of September 1879.

I hope all the Secretary that you will do all in your power to obtain from the Deptt. the reopening of that school and to give to those Indians a chance to receive education as well as the others who have no more right to a school than they have.

Your humble servant,

J. H. Dugger

MEMORANDUM

Applications for Grant for Salary of Teacher for Roman Catholic School at Michipicoten.

The school which was formerly in operation at Michipicoten was closed about 15 years ago, the Indians having removed from the vicinity of the H. B. Co's post to the reserve. $100 was, however, voted by the Government to pay for the removal of the school building, which has been re-built on the reserve, and is now ready for occupation, and the Roman Catholic authorities have for the last two years been applying for a grant to carry on the school, and in December of '97 Mr. Agent Van Abbott was informed that an item of $250 to provide for the salary of a teacher at this place would be included in the Estimates for 1897-98, and he was requested to inform the Rev. Father Specht at Fort William accordingly. This item was disallowed, and the Rev. Father Specht has renewed his application, and Father Dugas who has since succeeded Father Specht has called the Department's attention to this matter, and asked to have provision made for the teacher's salary. The Missionary states that there are about 20 children of school age who could attend if the Department consented to open the school. He states that he can obtain a substitute teacher and urges that the Department will make provision for having the school reopened after the summer holidays—in September next—as there is not other opportunity for the Indians to receive an education.

There are no funds available for this purpose, and the salary would have to be voted by Parliament.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Gentlemen,

I wish to write you to let you know, that we have moved with our families on our own Reserve at Gros Cap, built our own new house, and our Church is nearly completed, two deep more will finish it.

All we wish to ask of you is send us our teacher to the Reserve instead of Michipicoton River.

We are going to sell the School at Michipicoton River, and with that money will build a School on the Reser...
I have a house I will hire free of rent, until our school is built, as I am very anxious to have my children taught. I have a large family, and the children on the Reserve at present number fifteen in all. Kindly see that our teacher begins School again the first of September as usual.

Respectfully,

James Cass
Chief of the Michipicoten Band.

Michipicoten Harbor, Sept. 26th, 1901

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter dated the 26th Aug. last. In answer to that letter, I inform you that it is not the wish of the majority of the Michipicoten Band to have their school transferred from Michipicoten to Sora Cap. Notwithstanding requests of Chief Cass, I inform you that the Indians have not all moved to Sora Cap. I have written myself to Father Dugas, who was formerly charged with the spiritual care of the Indians here, to try to have the school continued in the old mission, for one year more at least.

There are now four or five families in the new place, at Sora Cap.
Father Bugo believes that if the school could start this new site, he would not attend it. Besides, some of these boys may attend the school during the winter in the old mission.

I believe then that there is no reason for changing the location of the school here.

Yours truly,

J. M. Spencer

Ottawa, September 12, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mrs. Skuse (Katie O'Connor) has applied for an increase of salary. She has had charge of the Indian school at Michipicoten since September 1901, and has been paid at the rate of $350 per annum. During that time the Department has been forced to raise the salaries of many of its teachers; in fact we are paying as high as $400 in a great many cases, and I doubt if we will in future be able to get any more teachers at less than $350 or $400. All that is provided for this school for the current year is $300, but I think that $50 additional might be included in next year's estimates, as the increased cost of living and difficulty in securing teachers for Indian schools seem to demand it, and when increases are made length of service should be taken into consideration.

Martin Benson

Sir,

Referring to your letter of No.

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of March 27th, 1909, referring to your proposal dated March 27th for land at Mohawk River for support of Public School there.

I did not reply to former letters as far as I had no means of obtaining the required information.

It appears that some of the members of Mohawk Band own lots in the village of Mohawk River and these lots are subject to rent as the case may be.

Should there be a school established here I do not think there would be any necessity to continue the Indian School as the attendance is very small averaging 8 or 10 attendants. I think a certain fixed sum might be paid for privilege of Indian children attending the public school. As Mohawk River is a long distance from here and to make a visit this time of year to test the waters would entail a big expense.

The Secretary Department of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

Mrs. Lagard here was telling me that you told her when here that they did not have to pay taxes and that they could not be assessed. Now I have looked this thing up and I find out that any nation living off of the reserve and occupying land are subject to taxes same as white people and I do not see why these people are exempt. They have an Indian school here but it should be one on the reserve that is the place for it, not here. If you have any law or authority or that showing that they are exempt let me know by return mail.

Geo Reed

Ottawa, July 30, 1908.

The Acting Deputy Minister,

A number of families of the Michiricoten River Indians reside at a point called "The Mission", some three or four miles east of the reserve. There is at this place a Roman Catholic Church and a school, to the latter of which the Department pays from the Parliamentary appropriation a grant of $350.00 for a teacher's salary. The building was erected by the Indians some twenty-nine years ago.

The influx of white settlers at this place has necessitated the formation of a school section under the Ontario Act, and the holdings of the Indians are within the boundaries of this section. Their property has been assessed for public school purposes, but the Indians consider that they are exempt from taxation and are refusing to pay the levy.

If the Indians have to pay taxes, there would not appear to be any need to keep up the Mission school, as they would be entitled to attend the public school; in fact the latter might be the better arrangement in any case.

I think the Law Clerk might be asked for an opinion as to their liability. The correspondence is on this file.

[Signature]

D. Clark
Ottawa, August 6, 1909.

Memorandum:

Assistant Deputy Superintendent General.

I have Mr. Scott's memorandum of July 30, in reference to Michipicoten River Indians' school matters, and beg to say:

1: That the property of Indians situated outside of a reserve is subject to taxation the same as the property of other people, and would, therefore, be subject to the public school rates unless the owners or tenants of the property are Roman Catholic and the supporters of a separate school in the municipality or the municipality contiguous thereto.

2: The Indians' Mission school here, while it is Roman Catholic, does not appear to be an established separate school under the act, but rather a private school maintained by the Department. Under these circumstances I am of the opinion that the property of these Indians is subject to the public school rates and that the Indians have therefore a right to attend the public school. And I would favour Mr. Scott's suggestion that it would not appear to be necessary to continue the maintenance of this Mission school.

Law Clerk.

Dear Sir:

During the past summer I have visited all the Indians on the north shore of the Georgian Bay, and on the west shore of Lake Superior. At Goulais Bay I met Miss O'Connor, then teaching in that school. This lady was engaged as teacher for several years in the Michipicoten River School.

She occupied rooms over the classroom of the school. She did splendid work in that school both as regards the secular instruction and moral formation of the children. I could see that in the children when I had them all before me for examinations on the occasion of my visit.

She is an excellent lady, and her good example had no small influence in the forming of the children.

For that District Mr. McRee himself admits that the fire was caused because of defects which the Department should have repaired in the school building and agrees that she should be compensated. In fact, the agent states that he has urged the Department to compensate Miss O'Connor for her loss.

The undersigned has the honour to report that on February 8, 1915, the Michinocoten Indian Day School was burned and that the teacher, Miss Annie O'Connor, lost all her personal effects.

The Indian Agent reported on June 9, 1915, that the fire was undoubtedly caused by a defective stove-pipe and not through any fault or negligence of the teacher. He explained that it had not been considered advisable to build a brick chimney because of the age and unsatisfactory condition of the building. The agent further explains the stove-pipe projected through the roof and consequently allowed the sparks to fall between the sheeting and the roof, and though at the time of the fire it was possible to save the school furniture and material, nothing could be taken out of the upper part of the building.

The accompanying inventory and statutory declaration attest to the fact that Miss O'Connor lost personal effects to the amount of $211.00.

MEMORANDUM:-

Mr. Perrier,

Re:- Proposed Combined Indian and White School at Michipicoten Harbour.

Mr. Agent Sims brought to my attention the fact that Mr. McCormick, Manager of the Algoma Central Railway, also Public School Inspector J. T. Walkom, had been discussing with him the possibility of establishing a Combined White and Indian Day School at Michipicoten Harbour. Michipicoten Harbour is located about six miles from the Michipicoten Reserve and Mr. Sims states that there are practically no Indians residing on the reserve at the present time.

In company with Mr. Sims, I met Mr. McCormick and Mr. Walkom on the morning of November 6th and, in the course of conversation, it was found that, in the event of a school being established, there would be the following children, at least:

T. Andree - 2 boys - 1 girl
J. Andree - 2 " - 1 "
W. Boyer - 4 " - 1 "
S. Andree - 2 " - 2 girls
Mrs. S. Cash - 2 "
Simon Lewis - 2 "

Total - 10 boys - 5 girls

Mr. Sims stated that all of the above are recognized as Indians.

In addition to the above, there would be six or seven white children whose fathers are working for the Algoma Central Railway and five children by the name of Perreault. This man was enfranchised about three years ago and is living at Michipicoten Harbour and, I understand
understand, has spent practically all the money which he obtained at the time of his enfranchisement.

Mr. McCormick and Mr. Walkom wanted to know what the Department would be prepared to do towards getting this school started and I informed them that, as it was not on a reserve, we would not be responsible for the securing of a building or equipping it.

Mr. Walkom estimated that, if a proper building was secured, the annual cost of operating would be approximately $1,400., and asked if, in the event of the school being started, the Department would favourably consider making an annual grant of $700. I informed him that I would bring this to your attention and was inclined to feel that the Department would be favourably disposed to assist to the amount stated.

Mr. McCormick and Mr. Walkom realized that the Department could not assume responsibility for the erection of the building and stated that they would be well satisfied if, in the event of this being secured, the Department would assist in the annual maintenance to the amount stated in the preceding paragraph. If you approve, I promised Mr. Walkom that an official letter would be directed to him in order to permit him to make his arrangements for the securing of a building and obtaining a grant from the Provincial Government.

Dear Mr. Helen,

Having inherited Father Proulx's Indian Missions along the east shore of Lake Superior brings me somewhat into your sphere of activity also. You may rest assured that I shall try always to be reasonable, just as you may rest assured that I will always respect your decisions, etc., knowing, as I have reason to, your integrity and justice. This is not what is commonly called "soft soap," but my sincere position.

Naturally the education of the children on the reserve is one of my biggest concerns, also as the salvation of their souls is intimately connected with it. The whole principle of Catholic education and Catholic schools is based therein. Catholic children cannot get in public schools the necessary Catholic education they are bound to get—and since we will all have to answer for it some day according to our responsibility, I feel under an obligation to write to you in regard to the Michipicoten Reserve children. I know of course that there are places where a Catholic school is impossible—but the question that confronts me is whether in the country a Catholic school is not only possible, but in fact justifiable and before God, due to the children of the Michipicoten Reserve. As things stand, I am told:

1) The reserve (Michipicoten) has no school;
2) The Michipicoten Band pays $700.00 a year for the support of the white school at the Harbour;
3) And the Indian children don't go to it because it is too far and too difficult in winter, and, they say, dangerous now (due to the necessity of passing under the ice bridge).

I am not infallibly informed—but has the reserve not a right or quasi-right to a school? Or would it not be able to support one for very little more than the $700.00 it now pays. And no matter what the cost, is there not their right to an education that is morally "possible," etc., to conditions that would make the school suitable to their circumstances.

It is true, the $700.00 must be quite handy for the whites—they can't have much to add to it.
in order to finance their school. But it doesn't seem just to the Indians, so far as I can see. I am told only one Indian child went regularly to school last year, and only 3 or 4 for a short time. And yet there are 26 children for school according to the list the chief gave me. I enclose the list with their respective ages.

Then there is the further fact that the Indian children are all Catholic— and the teacher at the Harbour is not. There is no need for me to develop this point. You can see the effect that must follow—the non-reception of what is most essential to these children, that is, a Catholic education. Catechism is only one point—it is not that that influences the children most—it is the Catholic method and attitude that a competent and worthy Catholic teacher would impart. And the fact that the missionary can only manage to go there once a month at the most makes the need for a Catholic and Catholic teacher on the reserve at Michipicoten and centralized power to make attendance possible the year round, all the more urgent and necessary.

I'm sorry I couldn't get this written to you earlier in the summer but it's never too late as long as the school is at the Harbour. I believe Father Paul Roma has already spoken to you about the matter in the past, and I trust you will pay your way here to provide the needed school. In the meantime, the funds are being wasted yearly as far as the Indians go—and not by the Indians—now can we say it is their fault—because the school is certainly too far, and it is outside the reserve, and takes the children off the reserve?—and it is not a Catholic school as they should have.

This letter may be long but I have tried to be clear—we know the situation and when things are written at length. I shall hope for a favorable reply. With every best wish,

Sincerely yours,

E. A. Primrose

Dear Mr. Phelan,

You will probably recall my petition of last Fall for a Catholic school on the Indian Reserve at Michipicoten. In your last letter you mentioned that Mr. McCookin would be visiting the Sault Agency and that he would look into the matter. I have asked Mr. Lawrence, the Indian Agent, at times if Mr. McCookin had come, but have always had a negative answer. The school year is advancing and summer will soon be with us so I am writing again to see if something could not possibly be done before the beginning of a new school term next Fall.

I don't think there is any need for me to go into the question of the need of a school or of its advisability again—I think that is clearly enough stated in my former letters.

Perhaps the Department is not prepared to make the outlay required to erect a school similar to that in other reserves. May I suggest then, in despair of a school like Neron Bay, Grand Bay, Longlee, etc., may I suggest that you permit the Indians themselves, or rather that you hire the Indians themselves to build a log school. It would provide them with work, and if properly directed should not entail any great expense. And if the Department has been able to pay from its own funds $700.00 a year up to now for the Indian
Children who went (or rather, didn't go) to the White school, then I think I can logically conclude that the Department could provide the salary for a teacher for the log-school that the Indians would build, and to which they would send their children—a thing they don't do at present in respect to the White school. The educational level of the Michipicoten Indian Reserve is honestly pathetic. The children, if left as they are, that is, to roam and idle the day long, are certainly not going to become more energetic or self-supporting as they grow older. Their ignorance will but increase and their indolence with it; And if later on they become franchised, they would make sorry citizens indeed. And the moral atmosphere can never be improved or uplifted in an atmosphere of ignorance and indolence, or in other words so long as the children's education is neglected as it is at present. These are the facts—I am not painting them up—I have been among the Michipicoten Indians long enough now to speak as I have, I think, and I beg of you to do something in regard to my request that I may not labour in vain.

Hoping that this matter will receive favourable attention, and early attention, that thus something may be done before the fall, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

C. A. Primau

The farthest Indian home from the present school is not more than a mile and a quarter away. While at Michipicoten recently I visited the opened school building, and found it practically without furniture. The following is a list of the articles which appear to me as indispensable to the proper carrying on of the work of the School, viz:

- A desk accommodation for 32 pupils.
- Teacher's desk and one chair,
- A hand bell,
- Cup-board & book-case,
- Stove-pipes & chimney,
- Hooks for coats, etc.
- Pail and drinking cup.

I am very well pleased with the progress, discipline & assiduity of pupils on my charge since Aug 27th. There are two families—one with six children of school age & the other with four who do not send their children regularly. The remainder give good satisfaction.

I have not yet received the school material I made application for on the 3rd inst., I will send in another 15 day warrant on it in case it should have been forgotten.

provided & I suppose be paid by Dept what ever it may be worth.

The school room is in a very dilapidated condition; it is extremely cold in the winter, it requires painting on the outside, the plaster has fallen off in many places, the inside, I think there should be a barrel of lime got there & repaired as soon as possible. We also require a brown dustpan & pail for the use of the school. All these things can be got here at the mission or across at Hudson Bay Post. SAULT STE. MARIE, ONT.
July 25th, 1928.

Re Building a School at Michipicoten River, S.S.#4.

Dear Sir:

I submit herewith a statement re attendance of Indian children at the Public School in S.S.#4 Michipicoten. Would you be good enough to forward same to the Department?

The store now in use as a school house is not suitable, and there is a probability that it will not be available after midsummer. You are familiar with the fact that no suitable building is available in this settlement, and that nearly all the children are Indian or half-breeds.

I understand your Department assume no obligation re education of non-treaty Indians; so that once an Indian is paid off in one sum in lieu of annual payments some other means must be provided for the children of such an Indian.

Now the time has come apparently when a school house must be built. The cost will probably be somewhat over $1200.00. I am prepared to recommend that the Ontario Department of Education make a special building grant of $500.00 if there is any means of financing the whole. Ventures in this area should not, I think, be considered. Would your Department consider a special building grant of $500.00? If so I shall advise the trustees to make immediate preparations for building.

Yours faithfully,

Mr. Agent Sims,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

June 11th, 1914.

Sir:

It has come to my attention in the organized township of Prince, is a settlement of half-breeds engaged in fishing and trapping. The population is mostly transient; but for the last few years at least there has been a school population of fifteen to sixteen children from five to fourteen years of age. Most of these children have never attended school.

Since I took charge as Inspector the following steps to provide educational facilities have been taken:

A school section was formed by the township council and a first meeting called for the election of trustees. At this meeting trustees were not elected.

Through a friend who spoke to me if three assistants could act if appointed trustees, this was unsuccessful.

Meetings of the ratepayers in the three sections in Prince were called to secure their approval for the election of a township board to conduct the business of all schools in the township. This was voted down in one section and in another section no one attended, there being only two or three resident ratepayers.

To meet this situation I am now again calling a meeting of the ratepayers for the election of trustees; but I do not know three persons competent to conduct the affairs of the section.
June 11th, 1924.

Mr. Fred Brown,

As the situation is somewhat similar to that at Attawapiskat Bay, where the Department of Indian Affairs provided for the education of the Indian-mostly half-breed children, I should be glad to know if the Department would consider assuming responsibility for the education of these children at Iron Dog. It is a serious thing to allow these children to grow up in ignorance in the midst of a civilized community.

I have the honour to be,

Yours faithfully,

signed,

J. T. Baldwin.

Mr. J. T. Baldwin,
Indian Agent,
176 Church St.,
Smith Street, Prince Rupert.
Dear Sir:

At Gros Cap on Lake Superior, in the organized township of Prince, is a settlement of half-breeds engaged in fishing and trapping. The population is somewhat transient; but for the last few years at least there has been a school population of sixteen to eighteen children from five to fourteen years of age. Most of these children have never attended school.

Since I took charge as Inspector the following steps to provide educational facilities have been taken:

A school section was formed by the township council and a first meeting called for the election of trustees. At this meeting trustees were not elected.

A thorough canvass was made to see if three competent would act if appointed trustees. This was unsuccessful.

Meetings of the ratepayers in the three sections in Prince were called to secure their approval for the election of a township board to conduct the business of all schools in the township. This was voted down in one section and in another section no one attended, there being only two or three resident ratepayers.

To meet this situation I can now again call a meeting of the ratepayers for the election of trustees; but I do not know three persons competent to conduct the affairs of the section.
June 11th, 1924.

As the situation is somewhat similar to that at Batchawana Bay, where the Department of Indian Affairs provided for the education of the Indian—mostly half-breed—children, I should be glad to know if the Department would consider assuming responsibility for the education of these children at Gros Cap. It is a serious thing to allow these children to grow up in ignorance in the midst of a civilized community.

I have the honour to be,

Yours faithfully,

signed—D.T. Walkom.

Mr. A.D. McLabb,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

On instructions of the Honorable the Minister of Education of Ontario, I have been making a survey of school conditions and needs at a point in the District of Algoma known as Gros Cap, where I find that school accommodation has been long delayed and most urgently required. There are some fifteen children of school age of whom four are treaty Indian children, the latter residing on the five acre reserve at above point. The only building available for use as a school is the "McCoy" house on this reserve now vacant and likely to continue unused, of which the present locate is Mrs. Barbeau residing at Goulais Bay. In consultation with your Agent at Sault Ste Marie, Ont., Mr. McNabb, he informed me that so far as he was concerned he would be pleased to recommend that this house be placed at the disposal of The Department of Education and would see Mrs. Barbeau personally in a few days and secure her terms.

As it is absolutely essential that speedy action be taken to avoid delay in levy of the necessary taxes, which delay would throw the opening of

Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the 21st ultimo, enclosing data as to the attendance and cost of maintenance of the school at Gros Cap during the last school year, I beg to say that, after full enquiry into the status of the children who attended, it is found that they are not Indians.

While Mrs. Ellen Gingras is in receipt of treaty money, her two children are not on the pay list. She is married to a half-breed, and the children take the status of the father. Mrs. Alex Neveau (Mary McCoy) is married to a white man, and the children are not in receipt of treaty money, and are also classed as half-breeds. The Collins girl was enfranchised with her father in 1922, and has ceased to be an Indian. She is not in receipt of treaty money.

I have the honour to submit herewith a letter from Miss Florence Hammond, Teacher of the Indian school at Sheguiandah on which is a report by Mr Indian Superintendent Ross.

A new School house is very much needed and I heartily endorse every word stated by the Teacher in her letter. I would strongly recommend, if funds are available, that the work be commenced as soon as possible. I thought at first that the old Church building might be pulled down and the material saved therefrom used in the construction of a school house; but on examining it I found that it would not pay to demolish it, the cost of doing so would amount to more than the value of the material in it. It might be used as a store house for wagons, sleighs, farming implements &c, and the old school house could be used as a Council house. I estimate the cost for the materials and work at about $450 and would recommend Mr James Lewis of Sheguiandah as a most reliable man to superintend the work.

As regards the supply of wood I am quite convinced that the Chief has not acted squarely in this regard or the matter of cleaning the school house. I would not however recommend that he be censured in view of the negotiations now pending with respect to the adjustment of the money and land matters of the Band.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the enquiries made by Bishop Thornloe in his letter hereunder, I beg to say that in the past the Department has accepted the nominations of the different churches carrying on missionary work for the position of teachers of schools in the outlying districts of the Province of Ontario especially on Manitoulin Island and the North Shore of the Georgian Bay. In the case of the particular school referred to, Sheguianadah—the present teacher Mr Reginald H. Ferris was nominated by the Bishop of Algoma and his temporary appointment was approved of by the Department. Mr Sims was distinctly informed that this appointment was only temporary and up to the present time it has not been confirmed.

I think that so long as the Department recognizes the right of the different churches to make nominations for the position of teacher, the latter should distinctly understand that he can only hold his position so long as he gives satisfaction to the Church authorities, who should have the power to settle disputes between the teacher and the missionary should any arise. I agree with His Lordship that no good results can be obtained on any reserve where the teacher and clergyman are pulling in different ways.

Sir,

The question of the tenure of office of teachers of denominational Indian schools has been brought to the Department, and it has decided that so long as it recognizes the right of the different denominations carrying on missionary work among the Indians in the outlying districts of Ontario, and especially on Manitoulin Island and the North Shore of the Georgian Bay, to nominate teachers, it will be the duty of teachers appointed on such nomination to conduct them selves to the satisfaction of the Church authorities if they wish to hold their positions, and should any dispute arise between the missionary and the teacher, the Church authorities are the proper arbitors of such disputes.

159-21. Sir,

I have the honor to report that Mr F.W. Major, the teacher at Sheguianah informs me that the pupils at his school are suffering from hunger during school hours, that many of them do not bring any dinner with them as heretofore and those who do have very little.

Mr Major asks that he be allowed to purchase a bag of flour and some butter and that his wife will bake the flour into bread and he will serve the pupils at dinner time with the rations. He states that it will be a month or six weeks before the Indians will be able to get work so as to provide for their families as they should be provided for. Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your favor of the 2nd inst. having reference to the decision of the Indian Department to close the Day School on the Indian Reserve here. I am both sorry and surprised that such a decision should have been arrived at without due warning being given and a thorough inquiry being made into the cause of the small attendance. No cause is given in your letter I only surmise that this is the cause.

I cannot think that it is in the best interests of the Indians to close a school so recently built and at considerable cost, and therefore self-denial, on the part of the Board. A day school, apart from its value as a teaching institution, is valuable as a means to turn the people to acquire settled habits, where if their children are taken away to industrial schools, the people carry to the camp with which they can imprint from place to place, abandon their homes and allow their children to run to wander forth and seek, and take to dissolute habits around the centres of civilization, where whisky and gambling play a very prominent part. And then, when their children, fitted for a more civilized mode of living than in the trading post institutions, return to their homes, there is no preparation. Angels where they can carry out more fully the knowledge they have acquired; but instead have to take occupation in questionable pursuits. Our Industrial Schools aim at doing a good work. But their aim is primarily to look after the Orphans and Destitute Children of our Indians, where it seems, as it was,
A second parent. But for the family life of the Indian I cannot see anything more beneficial than the way School and it is difficult to imagine what impression the Indians will get of such an act of the Department in closing an Institution which has existed for somewhere about 50 years without a break. There is, however, fault on the part of the Band in failing to appreciate the full benefit of the work by sending their children, and a threat only has the effect of weakening them to the situation, but I think it would be most unwise to close the school at this juncture, especially when the chief, James Papenack, who is a most efficient man, and whose re-election to the position is already making itself felt as he hastened to draw back to the centre various members of the Band who have, for various reasons, scattered away, and has succeeded in bringing back two families, which adds a nice children of about age to the list. There are now 18 children of about age, or about school age, resident on the Reserve, and I think it should not be difficult to maintain an average of from 9 to 10.

At a meeting of nearly all the male members of the Band held in Muskegina Hall yesterday morning, a resolution was passed, and unanimously carried, requesting the Department to reconsider their decision to close the school and have it re-opened after the holidays. At which time every one having children of school age would be assured to send their children.

In order to facilitate matters I propose to submit the following plan:

1st. That an adequate salary be paid to a teacher, whether of say $600 for the year after which, upon general approval, the amount be raised to $700 and in the case of a married man a dwelling be provided with privileges of farm for garden and firewood.

2nd. That certain provisions be made whereby children could organize a lunch.
During the warm hours, and that an equipment be maintained, as far as possible, for sports and calisthenics, and that the boys be instructed, in addition, in gardening, farming, and the care of stock, and the girls in sewing and housework, and that provision be made for this in the warm hours, and for time given to teach them additions if the teacher is not qualified.

That a School Officer be appointed at a nominal salary whose duty it shall be to see that children of school age be in attendance, in case of default that the parties responsible be brought before the Court, and be fined or imprisoned, as he may judge best.

I have little hesitation in saying that if these suggestions are carried out just deal better results will follow.

And I have most respectfully to ask the Department to consider their adoption and for the school another trial.

Believe me,

Very faithfully yours,

Geo. Pheon.

Dear Sir,

The matter of this letter is the teacher of the school on the Sheguandah Reserve. Since sending in my requisition for school material I have realized the necessity of having the children brush their teeth daily at the school. I have observed in adult Indians and even in those who have not reached their prime that their teeth are almost invariably in a state of decay. This of course must greatly affect the health of the community. Even the teeth of the children are very much in need of proper care. I have fifteen children in the register but hope for more and if the Department would send me two dozen toothbrushes and the necessary amount of tooth paste I shall teach them to care for their teeth taking care that the brushes are not used indiscriminately and that they where they might be infected from each other.

I shall also draw your attention to the position of the vacations allowed at Christmas.
and Easter which I think might be improved. On disagreeable days in the winter the Indian children spend their time around the stoves in unhealthy houses when they would be much more advantageously occupied in the sunny school-room.

In the spring, however, the temptation of playing outdoors in the woods and sunshine often interferes with their attendance and the school is at great restraint. Then they are very often needed by their parents to work at the seeding. I consider that they would make more satisfactory progress if school were kept open on Saturdays throughout the winter, and also through the Christmas vacation with the exception of Christmas Day, and then closed a corresponding number of days earlier in June. I should also mention that strawberry picking interferes with attendance in the latter half of June. At sugar making time the children all go with their parents to make maple sugar and if the Easter vacation, with the exception of Good Friday, Easter Sunday, and Easter Monday, were given them, the attention...
for that quarter would be considerably improved. If the Department sees fit to allow me to make these changes I am sure that the new arrangement would be more adapted to local circumstances.

Yours respectfully,

Douglas Murray.

Sir:

Referring to Official Letter No. 19-3-1 of the 25th ultimo, in regard to the report made recently by Mr. Inspector Hagan on the conditions of Sheguianadah School, I have the honour to report that I visited this school on the 4th instant, and found for the current quarter an enrolment of ten pupils with nine pupils present on the day of my visit and an average attendance of seven for the quarter so far.

The pupils are not progressing as favourably as they should, but on account of there being a great deal of sickness among the children on the reserve they were unable to attend regularly and, therefore, could not be expected to advance rapidly.

I spoke to several of the Indians pointing out to them how necessary it is to see that their children would attend school more regularly in the future, and if the school register did not show a better average for this quarter the school is liable to be closed and all the pupils of school age placed in residential schools. The Indians assured me that as now sickness had disappeared from among the children on the reserve they would see that the children would attend regularly.

I would most respectfully recommend that the school be kept open for the current quarter, and at the end of the quarter if the attendance does not show a better average, and better progress in the class-room, then, I would recommend that the school be closed.

Dear Sir,

Last month I made application to Mr. R. Lewis, Indian Agent, at Manitouwining, for the position of teacher of the Shequianadah Anglican Indian School. He replied that he had received no communication from Headquarters to remove Mrs. A. J. Abbott but would advise me when he did get orders to that effect.

Now, the reasons I applied for the said position are—deeply need it financially—as I have to support myself as my mother is a widow with very very small income which only partially takes care of her in her old age. I also
for teaching very much.

Then again, Mrs. Abbott's husband is a husky young man with steady work at good wages, and in his spare hours has a taxi service which is well patronized. He owns a cow, a horse, hens, and has a good house and excellent acreage of land in the village. From every standpoint he is well able to take care of his wife and her needs and so leaves the position which she now holds, free for one in my position to take care of ably.

Also Mrs. Abbott's teaching certificate is of the same standard as mine. I have taught for four years at the end of that period I had a nervous collapse but am in perfect health now.

The Indians under her tutoring are not as advanced as are the pupils in other Indian schools in this district.
Miss Abbott takes no interest at all in neither the Indian Church nor our English Church in the white village.

I would be very pleased if you would write Mr. F. Hardymon, our missionary here, and ask him if he will verify my statement. I know he would do so and would give you a clearer picture of the situation.

May I ask you to consider my request very seriously and grant an favourable reply to my appeal for help in securing this petition?

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

The Public School Inspector who inspected the Church of England Indian Day School on the Shagwianah Reserve, Manitouining Agency (Federal Electoral District of Algoma East) Ont., reports as follows, regarding the services of Mrs. Pearl Abbott, the teacher:

Dear Sir,

In reporting to the Honourable The Minister with reference to his recent visit to your agency, Dr. H. W. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs, wrote, in part, as follows:

"On our way to Manitowaning, we called at the Sheguianidah Reserve and visited the two schools - one under Roman Catholic auspices, being held in the church building. The teacher is Miss Lapointe and her total enrolment consists of six pupils. The Protestant school, under Miss Millantyns, has an enrolment of five. Both these teachers seem to be capable and further comment seems to be unnecessary upon the fact that we maintain two schools and pay two teachers' salaries for a total enrolment of eleven pupils."

In view of the many demands for new Indian schools in various parts of the Dominion and the further fact that our funds are limited, it is exceedingly difficult to justify the operation of two schools at Sheguianidah for such a small number of pupils.

Please let me know, at once, if there is any prospect of the attendance at either or both of these schools materially increasing during the academic year 1937-38. In addition, you should let me have as complete information as possible regarding the children attending both these schools at the present time and indicate if it would be feasible to have them attend a neighbouring White school to which a tuition grant could be paid.

You should, also, immediately notify both teachers that it is quite probable that both these schools will be closed at the end of June, 1937, and, consequently, if they are able to secure another position, they should do so. For your personal information, I may say that a final decision regarding the closing of these schools will not be made until your reply is received but, in order to protest the Department, the notice requested above should be given to both teachers. I will expect to hear from you in the very near future in connection with the situation at Sheguianidah.

Yours truly,

December 6th 1895

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of yours of 31st ultimo 1895 in reference to the Chipewyan School House. I would respectfully state that the building itself is very small and the ceiling low, but I think will be warm and comfortable in the winter as the Indians were going to build up the foundation when I visited the place last fall to do more.

I would suggest that lengthening the building be raised about fifteen feet with a new roof and a floor would cost from $400 to $500.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

With reference to the proposed new Schoolhouse - I beg to say that the Indians at Sheguinawak wish to build it...

1. It will be a Frame Building 25 x 18 feet.
2. Made of good sound lumber.
3. There will be a stone foundation.
4. The walls will be 2 x 8 in.
5. The ceiling 2 x 4 in.
6. The ceiling will be 18 ft from floor.
7. The roof will be pitched and covered with good shingles.
8. The floor will be lined with planed matched lumber inside (ceiling walls) (planks 3 ft.) varnished.
9. There will be two doors - paneled.
10. There will be 3 windows on each side - 2 x 4 ft. inside frame.
11. The outside sides with V-jointed siding - good.
12. It will be painted outside & inside with two coats paint.
13. It will be fitted with double inch boards - 1/2 inches.

Feb. 11th 1897

Deputy Minister,

I have examined the specifications referred to Ref. 182795 and have marked therein the amendments I would recommend.

Notwithstanding the extra cost, lath and plaster would be preferable to matched siding on the inside.

Mr. M. Hill states positively that the size of the building as stated in the specifications 18' x 24' is too small, that its size should be at least 18' x 30' (20' x 28' preferred).

Materials and labour are cheap in this locality. The building should cost about $600 and if matched to 20' x 28' about $600.

If the building is plastered on the inside, it should be two coat work with raincoating 3'-6" high laid on the first coat of plaster.

The specifications as amended are sufficient for this small building, but the ceiling as shown in some of the plans for such school houses prepared in this branch is preferable and is more satisfactory if the building were constructed in accordance with one of these plans.

S. Bray

Specifications for the erection of proposed Indian School-house and Out-buildings, and the laying out of School Grounds at.... Shequanda.

Description

The school-house building is to be a one-story frame structure on a stone foundation built in accordance with the accompanying drawings.

Foundation

Dig a trench (see plan of grounds for the location of the building) to receive the foundation for the walls of the schoolroom, cloak-room and shed, two feet deep and two feet wide, and hand lay a dry wall 20 inches thick to the level of the ground; upon this wall build with fair sized building stones a mason wall, well bonded, 18 inches high and not less than 16 inches thick.

Dig three pits 2 X 2 X 2 feet deep and at seven feet centres, as shown on the plan and build piers in a similar manner to the walls.

The earth is to be well rammed against the walls and piers to ground level.

Ventilators

Provide and place five common iron ventilators in the outside walls of the building, three on the southerly and two on the front elevation.

Chimney

The footing stone of the chimney is to be 6 inches thick. Build chimney of hard burnt brick and cement mortar, full joints. Brick to commence at top of mason wall. Build in the chimney from bottom to top a 12 inch diameter, 1/16 inch thick galvanized iron smoke stack, to be securely jointed together, and held to the side of the chimney shaft. The bottom of the smoke stack is to empty into a soot box, which is to be provided with a door opening say 18 inches above th
the floor, on the cloak-room side of the chimney.

Provide and place a large ventilating register, at least two square feet of surface, on the school-room side of the chimney at the bottom of the wainscoting.

Put in thimble and stopper for stove pipe.

Wall plates 2 X 8 inches, well bedded with mortar; Girder under centre of floor 6 X 8 inches; floor joists 2 X 10 inches at 16 inch centres. Put two rows of herring bone bridging of 2 X 2 inch stuff well nailed between the outside walls and the centre girder.

The studding to be 2 X 4 inch stuff doubled at the corners, and windows and door-frames well braced with two rows of braces. Wall plates double 2 X 4 inches, and doubled over windows and door openings.

The outside of walls to be first sheeted on the outside with 1 inch boards, put on diagonally close jointed and well nailed, and fitted closely to the windows and door frames; and then to be sheeted with 1 inch clapboards 5 inches wide, one ply of 12 oz. tar paper, well lapped, is to be laid between the above sheeting and clapboards.

The inside of the outer walls of the shed is to be rough boarded.

The rafters are to be 2 X 6 inch at 2 feet centres. Hip rafters 2 X 7 inches. The rafters of cloak-room and shed to be 2 X 5 inches, 2 feet centres. The tie beams of roof to be 2 X 6 inch, and 16 feet long, 2 feet centres. Belfry roof rafters 2 X 4 inch. All rafters to be properly framed and well spiked down.

Cover the several roofs with rough boarding, closely laid and well nailed to the rafters, and lay one ply of tar paper over same, well-lapped, and shingle.
with best sawn cedar shingles, 4½ inches to the weather dipped in Cabot's light moss green stain, Creosote Shingle Stain (Seymour and Co., Montreal) Finish roof with weather boards and roll complete. Lay tar paper under the eaves before sheeting.

Wainscoting

The walls of the school-room are to be wainscoted, 3 feet, 6 inches high, with narrow beaded sheathing. Finish with cap and Scotia and put quarter round at floor. The walls of the cloak-room are to be wainscoted to a height of 6 feet.

Doors and Windows.

Provide and hang with 3 - 4 inch butts the four doors shown on the plan. Inside doors to be four panelled 1¾ inches thick, 7 feet high and 4 feet wide. To have rebated frames 2½ inches thick. Provide and fix best 6 inch American locks to entrance and school-room doors, with two keys to each, and suitable furniture. Shed doors to have outside a good pad-lock and to hook inside. Put 7/8 inch thick oak thresholds at all outside doors and school-room door. The windows will be of the size and number shown on the plan. The frames to be fitted with 1½ inch pine double sliding lip sash hung and properly balanced with weights and heavy Silver Lake sash cord.

The whole of the windows to be fitted with 1½ inch winter sashes. Winter sashes to be divided into same number of lights as permanent sash with pane (the bottom middle) in hardwood frame arranged to slide horizontally. Winter sashes to be provided with strong hooks and eyes.

Wooden shutters.

The windows of school-room are to have outside wooden shutters of narrow vertical sheeting and to be hung in two leaves over the window sashes. Provide and fix all necessary window lifts and window and shutter fasteners.
Carry simple architraves at least 6 inches wide around windows and doors.

Floors.

All floors, except shed floor, are to be double, the lower one being of rough boards laid close and well nailed. The upper floor is to be laid with 7/8 inch tongued and grooved hardwood or selected pine flooring in narrow widths and blind nailed. Put a layer of heavy sheathing paper between the two floorings. The finished floor is not to be laid until after the plastering is done.

Floor the part of the shed where marked on the plan with 2 inch plank; floor to be carried on 2 X 10 inch joists laid at 16 inch centres.

The veranda floor and steps to be floored with 1 1/8 inch yellow pine tongued and grooved, flooring in narrow widths, laid with paint between joints.

The floor of the belfry is to be covered with galvanized iron.

Platform.

A platform is to be made on the floor of the schoolroom where shown on the plan. Joists 2 X 6 inches at 16 inch centres and floored same as school floor. Put on facing board and nosing complete.

Closet and Book-shelves

Build in a simple cloak closet, with one shelf, 7 feet high, and a book shelf with four shelves as shown on the plan. Height of book-shelf to be 4 feet from the platform.

Closet to have lock and key.

Lath and Plastering.

Lath and plaster the whole of the walls and ceiling of the school and cloak-rooms not otherwise specified. Plaster with two coats and hard finish.

The first two coats to be carried behind the wainscoting, architraves, etc.
Blackboard.

Provide and put in place above the wainscoting, at the back of the platform a framed blackboard 3½ feet by 10 feet of "Compo Slate Blackboard" or other approved material.

Belfry

Build a simple belfry as drawn on the accompanying drawing. The ceiling under belfry is to have a 2 x 2 ft. trap door with a suitable register framed into it. Lay on walk of 2 inch plank, 2 ft. wide and 6 ft. long from both sides of this trap-door across the ceiling joists.

Provide and place a bell to cost complete $5.00. The rope from the bell is to be carried on pulleys over the ceiling and to enter the cloak room in the chimney recess near the entrance from the porch.

Clothes hooks.

Provide and fix three dozen clothes hooks on the walls of the cloak-room. Hooks to be in two rows of 4 and 5 feet above the floor and staggered.

Painting

Knot, prime, stop and paint in two coat work the whole of the wood-work, not otherwise specified. The outside wood-work to be painted with white lead and linseed oil in two colors, light brown with dark brown facings.

Glaze all lights with clear medium heavy glass.

Water Closets.

The water closets, two in number, are to be built in accordance with the accompanying drawing.

Dig soil pits and Timber (cedar) the same as shown.

The lattice is to be of strips 2 X ½ planed and painted green.

Paint the outside in two coat work, same as school building, and white-wash the walls and roof inside.
Labor.

Indian labor to be employed under a white foreman as far as possible.

General

The whole of the work to be executed in a thoroughly workmanlike manner, and subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent, or other officer who may be appointed for the purpose.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the chimney on the new school at Sheguianah requires to be lengthened either by having the brick work extended several feet higher or by the addition of a metal stack or extension on the top.

The chimney works fine except with north easterly winds which come in with great force from the bay and blows the smoke down the chimney making the place uninhabitable during these wind storms.

I think that the better and more permanent way will be to have the chimney extended for four or five feet higher with the bricks thereby making a permanent job; the metal extension would come cheaper but would rust out in a few years.

The cost of making the extension will not be more than $15.00 I do not think and I would most respectfully ask for authority to have the work done at once before the bad weather commences.

Sir:

I hope it will not be asking too much of you to request you to give the following letter your earnest consideration, for it contains a request which if granted will greatly assist me in my difficult task of teaching the Indian children to use the English language intelligently.

I find the lessons too long as they are given in our readers. They of course are intended for our children who are familiar with the words orally & who have only to learn to recognize them written or printed. But the Indian child has to learn, to say the English words, their meanings & their relation to other words in the sentence, as well as to learn to recognize the words when written or printed, & frequently he has to develop new concepts before he can get an intelligent idea of the lessons in our readers. You can easily understand the tremendous task before us.
Indian child who has to learn a lesson as Book I, Part II, where he has no less than 73 new words (including the lesson on phonics) to learn before he can read the lesson at all intelligently. Any good teacher who has given serious thought to the subject will acknowledge that it is an impossible task. The child becomes weary & sick of the lesson before he has it half learned.

What I propose as a remedy is that such a lesson as this be taken as a review, & that before the child is asked to read this he should be given a series of short lessons using the new words given in the book, that the child be taught the words orally with their meanings so that he can use them intelligently in conversation, & then teach him to recognize the words when written or printed. Then he may be allowed to read the lesson in the book as a review. To do this requires more equipment than we have. It requires a great deal of blackboard space which we have not & if we had the blackboard space the teacher would not have the time to write out these lessons on the
Board without losing a great deal of time which could be much more profitably spent if he had other means of presenting the lesson to the children.

My plan is that the teacher be furnished a typewriter (which would be cheaper & much more convenient than a small printing machine) with which the teacher could print the series of short lessons at home, & after the children had learned each lesson orally & had learned to recognize all the new word when written on the board they could be given the typewritten lesson to read & to use it for seat work.

This would facilitate the task to a great extent & give the children a splendid practice in the use of English.

A cheap typewriter can easily be obtained which would do the work nicely.

Of course it would need to be one that would print distinctly, but the work on it would not be heavy.

Respectfully yours,

H.V. Major

Teacher.

Sir:

Referring to Official Letter No. 151707-5 of April 14th last, I have the honor to enclose herewith an account in favour of James Piabhwosch and William Gaikesheyongai amounting to $30.50 for repairs to the Sheguianah day school and closets.

Since I received official letter above referred to I have asked several plasterers to call at the school and make an estimate of the cost of having the ceiling repaired and submit the same to me, but I did not receive an estimate, and the ceiling was getting in such a dangerous condition, as the plaster was falling, that I made arrangements with these Indians to do the work at a wage of $2.00 per day to each, which is very reasonable.

As this school had not been whitewashed for years and had become very gloomy and unclean in the class room; I authorized the Indians to whitewash the walls of the class room while they had the scaffolds up for plastering.

The closets required cleaning and repairing which I also authorized them to do.

I would most respectfully recommend that this account be paid, as the work was done very cheaply, and the school is in good repair at the present time. If the work had been done by whitemen it would have cost a great deal more. The reason the Indians were so anxious to have the ceiling repaired, they were afraid their children would be injured by falling plaster.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Indian Agent,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have the honour to report that I visited the Sheguiandah Indian School yesterday the 5th instant, and on making a thorough examination of the building I found that the ceiling in the class-room is in need of repairs. The plaster is loose and is in danger of falling and doing harm to the children. I consider it would be well to take off the dangerous portion and replace with wallboard.

The exterior of the building has not been painted for a period of twenty-two years and is in need of repainting; also the roof requires some minor repairs. The steps at the entrance of the classroom are in a state of bad repair and require attention.

In order to have the exterior of the building repainted, the plaster on the ceiling replaced with wallboard and the necessary repairs to the roof and steps I estimate it would cost approximately $250 and I would recommend that this work should be carried out during the summer holidays.

I enclose herewith a resolution passed in council by the Band requesting the Department to grant the amount from the funds at the credit of the Band for the purpose of painting and repairs to the building.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I may say that the expenditure required will be paid from our appropriation for Indian education and not charged to band funds. Sir,

At the close of the last school year the Rev Richard Black, who was both Missionary and teacher of the Indian school at Naughton, was transferred by the Conference to another appointment. Before communicating with the Department about the appointment of another teacher I deemed it prudent to get information as to the prospects of the school. I now learn by a communication from the Rev A.P. Latter, of Sudbury, Chairman of the District, that there are in the band some fifteen children of school age, and it does not seem desirable that these should be left without any educational advantages. If a suitably qualified teacher can be secured will the Department assume responsibility in regard to salary on the same basis as the other schools that were taken over on the 1st of July? In the past the Department has been paying $200 per annum, but a properly qualified teacher could not be secured for less than $300, and even then it is probable that we would have to supplement that amount so as to induce a married teacher to take up his residence at Naughton. We own a house at that place, and it will be available for the teacher if the work goes on.

OTTAWA; 23rd September, 1902

The Secretary:

With reference to the application hereunder from Mr Carmichael of Naughton to have the school fees for his children who are attending the Indian school there reduced, I beg to say that 25 cents per month, the amount he is called upon to pay is the lowest charge made by the Department for such pupils and I do not see how it could very well be reduced.

This is the first intimation the Department had had that any white children were attending this school and if Mr Windsor is collecting fees he should be called upon to transmit them to the Department.

This is one of the schools taken over from the Methodist Church and the average attendance (3.5 for the past year) is so small that the Department is hardly justified in carrying it on. The number of white children who wish to attend would in no way interfere with the instruction of the Indian pupils and I think it would be an advantage to the latter to have them there. Any non-resident has to pay school taxes on property and if Mr Carmichael is obliged to live at Naughton he should dispose of his property at Whitefish on which he assessed, either by lease or otherwise, and I would suggest that he be informed accordingly and that Mr Windsor be asked
to report on Mr Carmichael's statements, through Mr Agent Sims.

Martin Bussard

SIR,

The Department was informed months ago that White Children were attending, as an examination of my reports will show. They attended under my predecessor, it has been the custom for them to attend for years, and to pay fees. I have received $1 in cash. Besides this I received a little wood a few qts of milk and about two or three lbs of Butter probably about $4. worth altogether.

I should like to purchase a dictionary for the study of Indian but cannot afford it out of my meagre salary. I have never received a cent for correspondence during the years I have been in the Indian Service. I have to put on fires. As I made no secret of the Whites attending, there was no thought of wrong. Dr Sutherland was informed and advised me to exercise my judgement.

I enquired carefully as to the custom of my predecessor. My chief reason was to develop a sense of obligation and avoid pauperizing the whites—a needful protection here. I shall be glad for the Department to fix the fee and relieve me of the responsibility. It should not be less than 25 cents. At Copper Cliff, 7 miles distant the charge is 50 cents; at Sudbury 11 Miles distant it is $1. per month. It should be paid in advance, the people can afford it. May I suggest too that discretionary power should be allowed the teacher as to the admission of the whites, so that he may be able to guard the interests of the school and of the Indians.

Carmichael's began in June. There was another family here but they have removed. There are 7 Whites settled in the neighborhood of school age. The Indians who were absent have returned. They left nearly two years ago on account of Small-pox and have had no schooling since. They came back in the holidays but left again to make arrangements for a final return. Their last return occurred about two weeks ago, since when they have been attending very regularly. I have now 11 Indian pupils on the roll, the average for the last two weeks has been over 10. I expect about that average for the current term. They, parents and children are anxious for schooling.
I have worked assiduously and faithfully. The small population accounts for the small attendance in the past. This is now changed.

It seems to me that the Department and agt should support me against the attempt of illiterate and unscrupulous white people to domineer over him and the Indian School.

Yours truly,

Signed, J. A. Windsor.

Sir,

When Mr Benson was at this place during the present month the question of keeping open the school at Naughton was discussed and I mentioned to him that I was of the opinion that it was only wasting money in keeping this school open on account of the very small attendance, that the Protestant children of school age could be sent to some Industrial institution and the Catholics to Wikwemikong and better results obtained. Mr Benson agreed with me in this.

I am just now in receipt of a letter from the teacher of the Naughton school, Mr J.A. Windsor, in which he informs me that the school was opened on the 21st August and has been kept continually open since that time on school days but without the attendance of a single child. In view of this do you not think it would be well to close the school at the end of this quarter?

Reverend Sir:

I have to call your attention to the unsatisfactory attendance at the White Fish Lake (Waukton) Indian School. The average last year was less than four pupils, and our Agent has written stating that he is in receipt of a letter from the teacher, Mr. Windsor, informing him that the school was opened on the 21st of August and has been kept continuously open since that time, but without the attendance of a single child; and the agent considers that in view of this, it would be well to close the school at the end of the quarter. Before taking action the Department has decided to advise you of this state of affairs and ask for your views. It would appear to be impossible to improve the attendance at this school, as most of the Indians have left the neighborhood; it seems to be a great waste of money to keep the school opened for such poor results.

Ottawa, June 14, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. MacKenzie has asked me to write with reference to the establishment of an Indian day school for Roman Catholic children at Sheguianidah. I may say that our latest census shows the total population of this reserve is 119, with not more than 30 children of school age. This indicates that only one school can be successfully conducted on the reserve. If a proportion of the children that should attend the present Sheguianidah Day School are Roman Catholic in religion, the Department will consider making the school non-denominational in character. The teacher would be appointed by the Department and both Protestant and Roman Catholic missionaries would be given an opportunity to give religious instruction to the children of their own faith. If this arrangement appears satisfactory to you, if you will let me know, the Department will write the Bishop of Algoma in the matter.

Little Current,
Ont.
June 19, 1929

Dear Sir,

I thank you for your letter of the 14th Inst., No. 19-3-1 regarding a catholic day school for the Sheguianish Reserve.

Considering the stand of the Department about the Shishigwaning Schools, since the last fifteen years, your suggested combination has brought me a great surprise. Our missionaries are very warmly opposed to every sort of undenominational schools because the Catholic Church disapproves of them, and also because they are particularly unsatisfactory on Indian Reserves. The school being the continuation of the family, we are supremely anxious to have catholic schools for our catholic Indian families. The teaching of religion should permeate all other subjects, and not be given separately. Just as the various materials that serve to make a cake should be cooked together and not separately. For this reason, the vast majority of Indian schools have always been denominational.

The proposed system of religious instruction given alternately by Protestant & Catholic Missionaries in that neutral school would be difficult to realise, because the pupils of the opposed denomination would have to leave the class room during the religious teaching. Moreover, general experience proves that Protestant Parents are reluctant as much as Catholics in sending their children to neutral schools; so that in these schools the attendance is as poor as the character training. In the present case, apart from the fact that nearly eighty per cent of the Parents are asking for a catholic school, since more than twenty out of the thirty children of school age are Catholic, is it fair to deprive them of such catholic school as other Reserves enjoy?

We can guarantee an attendance of twenty; there are many Indian rural schools with less pupils on their Roll; may we not expect an equally just treatment for the catholic pupils of Sheguianish?

The new catholic school of Shishigwaning, built in 1912, could have most comfortably accommodated all the pupils of the Reserve; notwithstanding, an Anglican school was built for the Anglican pupils.

Contrary to this, the old Anglican school of Sheguianish, is in poor condition; the principle of religious freedom, invoked for the Shishigwaning Anglicans, should be at least equally applied to the Sheguianish Catholics, since the old school is not sufficiently equipped.

We feel that we are not asking an unreasonable favor, but simply the ordinary logical means to educate our Catholic Indian children.

Trusting that you will deign reconsider our most ardent request, I remain,

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

With reference to Father Papineau's request that a Roman Catholic School be established on the Sheguinah Reserve, I have to state that the Anglican School there has been conducted for practically 50 years. During this time, the church authorities have been given the right of nominating the teacher. At the present time, there is Mrs. A. J. Abbott in charge. She has an enrolment of 18 and an average attendance for the past year of 10. Earlier reports indicated that approximately two-thirds of her enrolment were of her own faith, i.e., Church of England, so, evidently, some of the R.C. children have attended.

Our latest Census gives a total population for the reserve of 119, with 48 R.C. - just 40%. Our Census shows that 29 children all told are of school age. This indicates that one day school can be successfully operated on the reserve.

Father Papineau does not appear to like the denominational school arrangement, with both missionaries having the right to instruct the members of their flock in religious education for one hour per week. It is really necessary to get at the actual facts, and it would be well for the Department Inspector to secure the names of the children of school age living within 3 miles of the school and indicate on this nominal roll the religion of each child.

Deputy Chief, General of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir:

It is now nearly 25 years since I took spiritual jurisdiction over the Indians of Northern Ontario between Fort William and Mattawa, including those on the Manitoulin Island. During all those years I have not troubled the Department very much either in person or by letter with many demands or requests to promote the welfare of the Indians under my jurisdiction. Heads of religious denominations venture to operate with much fewer Indians under them, have both seen the Debt much more than I have without the faintest suspicion that I can be charged with boredom by the Department. I am writing today in order to bring to your attention a school which the Catholic Indians of Shequindah have forwarded to your Department. There are twenty Catholic children of school age in that Shequindah Reserve—there are five Anglican children and three have their school.

It is surely quite reasonable to me that there should be a school for these 30 Catholic children only! I have confidence that the Department will give them one. The social morals and spiritual welfare of these Indians can be best promoted by seeing that they are thoroughly grounded in the teachings of Christ and the Church.
They can get very little religious instruction if it is not imparted systematically, by at least a half hour each day in the school. The parents are too ignorant to give it to them, and Rev. Mr. Robinson, the Roman Catholic missionary has not time to do it for them because he has so many places to attend, that he can visit that the mission only once a month at most, and that often on a week day. Religious instruction once a month in the Church is entirely inadequate to the school is necessary in these circumstances for the Christian formation of these native children.

There is a movement already on Manitoulin Island for two denominational schools for the same Band of Indians, and that is the situation where there are both Catholic and Anglican schools.

Since the Anglican minority of Shoiguawing has its own Anglican school with the Anglican missionary in charge as teacher (which I highly approve) the best, and I am sure yourself shall be very pleased to grant the petition of the Shoiguawing Indians and provide them with the school which they desire for their children. Respectfully requesting you to favorably consider and grant this request which I submit to you. I am, dear Sir,

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. Mr. Sellards

Bishop of S.S.M.

Dear Dr Scott:

When I visited Manitoulin Island about six weeks ago, Father Papineau took me to Sheguiandah, and pointed out the need of a Catholic school there. The district roundabout is, I believe, almost entirely Catholic, and there is a chapel there where Father Papineau says Mass once a week, or oftener.

Yesterday I received a letter from Fr Papineau, together with copies of correspondence he has had with your Department regarding the school; and I am pleased to note that an Inspector is being sent to investigate and report on the facts of the case.

If these are what Fr Papineau represents them, I do not see how in fairness his request can be refused.

Fr Papineau is not a trouble-maker, as everyone knows, but he has waited patiently a long time, and is now very much in earnest about securing this school. So too are the Catholic Indians of Sheguiandah, who will not fail to see, rightly or wrongly, discrimination against themselves. They instance the case of the small minority of Anglicans at Shishigwaning, who have had their school, and who were not forced to go to the school of the majority.
and again they cannot understand why their petition should be denied on account of alleged rights of a tiny minority, when those rights were not supposed to exist when they themselves happened to be the minority. Now did they claim them.

I feel sure that you will understand that I am not desirous of seeing trouble fomented on religious grounds, but that if I write thus frankly (as I am sure you would have me do) it is in order that trouble may be avoided. I am fully aware that it is not easy, sometimes it is even impossible to please all parties, and I would not make your task any harder or more unpleasant than it is. But in the long run, the one who looks only to justice and fairness, gains the consideration of all. That such is your desire, namely to be kind to all and impartially just to all, I know to be a fact, and I think that all recognize it. If some do not, they should.

I cannot see any fair or any satisfactory solution save only that which the Indians and Fr Papineau have asked for. Certainly a public, non-denominational school would not be acceptable. It would certainly be rejected by the Catholics, and I should hope by the Anglicans also. Better almost the unfairness of the Catholic majority being forced to attend a school of an Anglican minority; than to have that colourless, undesirable hybrid, the Indian public school.

A solution suggested by some one, namely that the Catholics should continue to attend the Anglican school, but that the missionaries might petition the Bishop of Algoma to teach in it
could not be entertained seriously.

The only solution that to my mind appears the least bit practical is the simple and straightforward solution that the Catholic Indians are asking for. Any other will, to my mind, lead to trouble, and will give rise inevitably to a sense of unfairness, which would be most unfortunate and regrettable, and which is so hard to lay.

I hope you do not mind this rather hurried letter, written to catch a train. I have not had time to choose my words, but you will make allowances.

With very warm personal regards, I beg to remain, dear Dr Scott,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]
