Mr. Ferris,

When inspecting the Manitowaning Agency on the 10th instant, the Sheguianah Indian Day School question was taken up with Mr. Indian Agent Lewis. I did not see Father Papineau as he had left for Montreal to be gone two weeks.

According to statistics given me by the Agent, there are at the present time 16 pupils on the roll, 10 of whom are Anglican and 6 Catholic. There are 5 families belonging to this section who are absent and not permanent residents on the reserve. Three of these are reputed to be Catholic and two Anglican. In the Catholic families there are 5 children of school age and 3 in the Anglican families, making a total of 13 Anglicans and 11 Catholics of school age.

There appears to be some difficulty in getting an absolutely correct census of those who are Catholic and who are Anglican. The Agent informs me that a number of the families are not very devout and switch from one religion to the other easily. On the other hand there are a number of Anglicans who would strenuously oppose any change in the present school system.

A complete census of all the children in this section up to 15 years of age should be taken, showing the number of each denomination attending school and those who will be eligible later on. It may be that when the children come up to school age, there will be a sufficient number of pupils to warrant the erection of another school in this section in the near future. This course, in my opinion, would solve the problem in the most satisfactory manner.

Dear Dr. Scott:

As I have been absent on visitations in Muskoka for the last three weeks, I regret that I have not been able to send a reply sooner to your letter of July 30th concerning a proposal to open a separate school for Roman Catholic children on the Sheguiandah Indian Reserve.

While I have much sympathy with the desire of the Roman Catholic clergy to bring up their children in their own Faith, and can appreciate their contention that an undenominational school does not satisfy them in this desire, yet I would submit that the present state of affairs has arisen entirely owing to their own action; for if you will refer to a letter from Mr. W. Sprague, Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, dated June 21st, 1867, to the Rev. J. W. Sims, Church of England missionary to the Indians on the Manitoulin, you will see that it was laid down that the Reserve should be maintained solely for Protestant Indians and that Roman Catholic Indians should not be permitted to locate themselves there, in order to promote unity among the Indians and to avoid religious controversy. In spite of this decision, Roman Catholic Indians have gradually crept into this reserve. Of course 1867 is a long time ago, but the Roman Catholic Indians have a large Reserve of their own on the Manitoulin, with which we have never interfered, and their present demand, therefore, seems an unreasonable one.

The multiplication of small schools is, of course, most unsound on educational grounds, and there can be no two opinions as to its being a great waste of money. The only suggestion of any practical value that I can make is that the Roman Catholic authorities should be allowed to withdraw their children for a certain period daily (or two or three times a week) to their church, which is quite near, or to some house, in order to receive religious instruction from their priest. I should not myself raise any objection to this procedure if it would
suit them, as I think it reasonably ought.

With kind regards,

Yours very sincerely,

Sir:

Chief Maisheguongai has applied for himself and his band for information as to whether they may select land next spring, at Shahgwa,an,dah Bay. He says he does not wish the land immediately on the river emptying there, but abt. a mile to the South, along the water front. The Indians generally wish to locate the lands to be allotted to them at this place - that is the Protestant Indians, - they wish to have a reserve to themselves, apart from the Catholic Indians - and they will be very much disappointed if they are prohibited. On the other hand there is a good mill site there, and from its position, and the good land, about it, it would be likely to become a village - I am informed that from the time of the surrender they have looked forward to settling at Shah gua, an, dah & it would give those Indians who are trying to incite trouble, an opportunity of making further mischief if they were not allowed to do so.

In connection with this subject I have the honor of submitting for your consideration - in relation to the removal of the establishment from here to Little Current next spring - that with the doubtful exception of its situation it does not possess the advantages that Manitowaning does. For two or three miles immediately about the village site, the land is swampy & poor & when beyond that you come to the good land, there is not nearly as much of it, as about this place - neither is the climate there so good as here, being more
variable on account of its proximity to the main land and the current flowing fast. Again to move there will require the erection of new buildings, & the abandonment of those here - the situation of Manitowaning is more central, and by a short portage water communication is had by South Bay with Lake Huron & Georgian Bay much nearer to the settled part of the Province than from Little Current - while by Lake Manitou all around the shores of which is good land - communication is had for 20 miles into the interior of the Island & by another very short road the North Channel is again reached. The land intervening between Manitowaning & South Bay & Lake Manitou & for some distance on its North shore is excellent, and when the present unsurrendered portion of the Island is ceded, it will surround Manitowaning with the best land on the Island - If the petition of the Indians for land at Shahgus, an,dah is granted they will require the larger part of the good land about there, and Little Current, and Little Current will be on an isolated point surrounded by swampy land - with an Indian Reserve intervening between it & the rest of the Island - An increased inducement to intending settlers to locate lands in this neighborhood is that here we have a fine Church and a Church of England Minister - the Rev. Mr. Jacobs, which it would be some time before they could have at the Current - As regards the objection that it is out of the steamboat route I beg to submit, as by reference to the map you will see, that from Wekwemikong Point it is not any farther in here than it is to Killarney where
the boat now touches, while to Killarney the Channel is intricate & dangerous, besides keeping the boat in the open Bay longer than if they gave up calling at that place & came in here - The water in this Bay is very deep & a steamer would experience no difficulty in coming in here at any hour of the night - Killarney is a barren desolate place with not nearly the same claim to a mail as Manitowaning - There is no church nor school nor Minister of the Gospel there & no Government officer but the Postmaster- Its only importance is that it is a small trading post for fish, & its only population a few half breed & white traders - I believe about half a dozen - The present arrangement is that the mail for this place is left by the boat at Killarney & sent in from there in an open boat - By the boats discontinuing to going to Killarney & coming here instead the mail for that place could be forwarded from here, instead of as now from there here - Again the houses here need not be abandoned - An early & positive decision is very desirable as to the place at which the Government establishment is to be, as the Indians are enquiring for land & will be governed in some measure as to their choice by the position of the Superintendent & other officers - And also if next spring a change is contemplated, it will be necessary at once to make arrangements for getting out timber for building as there are no houses away from here.

I have the honor to be
Sir
Your most obt. servt.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th December last relative to a desire expressed by Chief Maisheguongain and his Band to take up the allotments of 100 acres for each of their families in the vicinity of Shiguendah Bay under the provisions of the Treaty of October 1862, I have to state that the Surveys having progressed to the degree which they have done I do not see that any objection would exist to their deciding upon the Lots which they will apply to you to locate them for upon your being furnished with a map of the Survey.

I see no objection to the Chief and his people taking up their land, a mile to the South E. end of the stream which empties into the Bay, with the understanding that the intervening land is not to be taken up by the Indians but reserved for sale. And if they can be induced to commence the settlement at a rather greater distance off it would be so much the better. You can explain to them that when a mill is erected a village with shops and other places of business would no doubt spring up and that their people would be safer from temptation, and better off by settling at some distance from such a village; while the distance would not be such as to prevent them visiting it when business required it.
Their social and moral condition will not be improved by their being in very close proximity to a Town or Village - And as the lands close thereto, will sell for the best prices, their funds will benefit by their not themselves taking possession of the most valuable lands - You will have the goodness to settle them as compactly as possible and having reference to keeping together the little Communities formed by special and particular associations which bring them together by bonds of feeling which they hold in common one with the other. This will tend to promote harmony and contentment among them. I allude especially here, to the wish which appears to prevail among the Protestant Indians to be allowed to take up their land together. To this reasonable request there can of course be no objection. You will have the goodness to examine the Treaty very carefully and make it exactly your guide in locating them in compliance with its conditions. At the same time you must endeavour to impress upon them the fact that they must be content to take a lot although but a portion of it may be fit for cultivation, and that the sale of the lands in a manner beneficial to them will depend upon their leaving for sale a sufficient quantity of land of good quality to induce white settlers to become Purchasers.

Dear Mr. [signature],

Your kind letter of October 5th was received by me, upon my return from Indian Missions in Minnesota.

First, I must tell you my gratitude for giving me an opportunity to answer the charges made against us by some officials of the Anglican Church, and I hereby ask you, as a very particular favor, to allow us the same privilege whenever such charges are laid against us.

Await your return,

[signature]

Re: Annie Syjigobinaw (or Kay apple is wrongly called) her illegitimate child Joseph, enrolled in our Church by Catholic baptism, and 7 years of age, had never gone to school. Last summer, Annie Syjigobinaw arranged to place her boy (illegitimate) Joseph with his godmother, Mrs. Paul Naodzyig, at Shingwauk, where she brought the child, with the understanding that he would...
go to our school. Please note that therefore Rev. Mr. Weeks, Anglican minister at Little Current, had never bothered with this pupil. As soon as he was informed that young Joseph was going to our school, he raised quite a fuss, and coaxed Anna Sigognews to withdraw her boy from the godmother's home, at Sheguindah, and bring him back to Little Current. At present, young Joseph is in Little Current, Sucker Creek, etc., etc., but does not go to school; (the old story of the dog in the manger). Moreover Anna Sigognews, who has two illegitimate children, is living in humble penury, with Chuck Boyter, a professional drunkard. I leave you to decide whether the boy Joseph is better protected in that house of ill-fame and away from school, or with the Catholic godmother, in Sheguindah and going daily to our school.

Re the other specific case, Charlotte Mitchell.

Two years ago, Mrs. Noah Mitchell gave by written document, to her mother, Mrs. Paul Navodigew, the said Charlotte Mitchell. This wild child has been living all over the district: back of West River, in Sheguindah and in Whitefish Falls. About one month ago, as I was driving by Whitefish Falls,
Wilson Esquimaux, the second grandfather of Charlotte, told me: "Take Charlotte to her grandmother, Mrs. Paul Naodiging, at Shagwundah; it would be a good thing that she go to your school there, where she really belongs."

In all good faith, because Mr. & Mrs. Noah Mitchell and Charlotte live in the very house of Wilson Esquimaux, I took the grandfather's authorization and brought to Shagwundah, Charlotte, who was glad to accompany me. The next day, our Hardeman, acting minister for the Anglican Church, at Whitefish Falls, got highly hysterical; accused me of kidnapping children; and subjected Mr. & Mrs. Noah Mitchell to summon me before the Crown Attorney.

It was a huge joke! Rev. Mr. Weeks drove hastily to Shagwundah and demanded Charlotte from the grandmother. As this said Charlotte is a bad child, I had promised to allow the grandmother to send her in our school, solely because she was baptized in our church. We had to clothe her, and prevent her from skipping the other pupils. I was not anxious to keep her.

Re Wikwemikong, South Bay, etc.

First I might suggest the strangeness.
of the fact that the Anglican officials will meddle
with Wikwemikong, and South-Bay where they have
not a single member of their church.
As I explained to Mr. Ferrier, there is a saw
mill in Shegwandah. Some Wikwemikong
Indians are working in that saw-mill and
have their family near the mill, since seven or
eight years. Naturally their children are pupils
in our school.

Wilfred and Joseph Sannawehi, born at Wikwe-
mikong, have lived frequently, and their grandmother's
home, and John McKatebin, at Shegwandah.
Since two years nearly, their mother has left
her husband, Grace Sannawehi, and lives in
scandalous union with Joseph Talkwadjiwan, in
Blind River. — As a natural consequence,
Grace Sannawehi has left his two boys with
John McKatebin, at Shegwandah, where they
regularly frequent our school.

I am ready to assert these allegations under
oath. — Trusting that they will bring
things to their former peaceful conditions.

I remain your obedient servant,

Eug. A. Papineau

Dear Sir,

Mr. Rafferty has notified me that no estimates have been marked for the construction of the Catholic school on the Sheguianah Indian Reserve. Considering that the subsidies for Indian education have not yet been voted; and that this question cannot easily be settled by merely adding the comparatively small sum of $3000.00 to the proposed building expenditures in fairness for your Department as well as for the Sheguianah Indians, may I beg you to reconsider our many solid reasons to be supplied with a convenient school building by next September.

1. The use of St. Anthony's church puts us to many serious inconveniences. It is not central; it is very hard to keep warm; consequently does not give much inducement to good attendance. Moreover, as we had to replace the pews by school desks, the parishioners are greatly inconvenienced on Sundays. We readily suffered this heavy drawback during one year, but the prospect of repeating it during twelve more months is not very pleasant. We have saved expenses to the limit of economy; we have no teacher's desk and the only piece of furniture we asked for the teacher's residence was a small box stove.

2. We fail to see the good excuse for one more long year of "observation," in view of the fact that in Sheshogwening year 1929, your Department has, without any long "observation," built an Anglican school for just the three families of David Samson, Paul Okeda & John Migunigewa. In Sheguianah, there are thirteen Catholic families. Besides being sufficient to warrant the future of the school, this number will be increased by the progressing local industries of: a saw mill; a silica quarry; a fishing station and the large house of "The Manitoulin Gardens."

Sheguianah is an active centre and not decline as Sheshogwening did.

3. The fact that some of the present pupils do not belong to the "Band" can not justify the refusal any more than at Birch Island, where fourteen of the pupils do not belong to the Reserve.

4. We love to picture your Department as the patronization of British Policy, but we cannot help comparing the readiness and facility with which the Sheshogwening Anglican School was established, together with the long arduous difficulties we have experienced in obtaining the Catholic school of Birch Island; and the actual painful supplications to obtain a school for Sheguianah a similar school whose future is promising as good a success as that of Birch Island.

5. With an average attendance of thirteen for the whole year, our Catholic school of Sheguianah has more pupils than a great many Indian Day-schools, in Ontario and the other provinces of Canada.

6. Owing to the proximity of the building material, a replica of the Boswa School could be erected in Sheguianah for the sum of $3000.00.

7. The Catholic Indians of Sheguianah who constitute the majority of the Band are very anxious to have a suitable school building, and join me in this earnest request for a more favorable consideration of their needs and rights.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

June 22, 1931.

I wish to report that, when at Little Current and the Sheguinandah Reserve recently, I went very carefully into the question of the Roman Catholic School, which has been started in a church, just off the reserve, by the Rev. Father Papineau. You will remember that, as from September first, 1929, the Department has paid salary to the teacher. The Church authorities and others are requesting us to provide a suitable classroom.

When the Sheguinandah Reserve was established, it and the Sucker Creek Reserve were supposed to be for the Protestant Indians of that time. At Sheguinandah particularly, Catholic families have settled and it has been necessary to make a decision concerning a separate school. Mr. L. F. Hardyman, Church of England Missionary there, has indicated it was his understanding that the Catholic families should not be allowed to settle on this reserve and he has somewhat bitterly opposed the establishment of a separate school. I informed him that, whereas the reserve may have been established for Protestant Indians 50 years ago, the Department could not guarantee that the Indians living there would remain Protestant. I also stated that Indians from other reserves in the vicinity, whether Protestant or Catholic, would not likely be prohibited from moving to Sheguinandah provided they had an opportunity of bettering themselves from an economic standpoint. It appears that, recently, the Indians at South Bay have had a difficult time and they are leaving there and are having somewhat better luck at Sheguinandah.

I made a careful examination of the nominal
roll at the R.C. School, interviewing both Mr. Hardyman and Father Papineau, concerning each child, and, along with Agent Lewis and Inspector McCookin, visiting some of the homes, in an effort to secure additional information. I learned that 7 of the children were clearly eligible for a Catholic school; that 9 or 10 others might be considered importations to the reserve and in the case of one or two additional, the religious affiliation was doubtful.

Of the 10 that appear as if they might be importations for the purpose of bolstering the claim for a separate school, 2 are living with their grandmother, a resident of the reserve, the parents being separated, 2 are living with an aunt, as their own home near Whitefish Falls was distant from an Indian school, 2, along with their mother, originally from Grassy Bay, are staying with a resident of the reserve, and 2 are living with an aunt who is looking after them, there being no school near their own home at South Bay. I am quite satisfied that Father Papineau is assisting with the board for these children.

The fact remains that there are nearly 20 Roman Catholic children living on the Sheguinandah Reserve and I take it that it is the Department's duty to educate them. In addition, there are 9 younger children who will be eligible from year to year.

During the fall and winter terms of the coming academic year, it will be seen if those children which might be called "Imported" are to remain more or less permanently on the Sheguinandah Reserve. This will assist in a decision whether or not funds should be provided for a classroom. A teacher's residence may not be necessary, as the white community at Sheguinandah is less than a mile away from the population centre of the reserve.

Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

With reference to your memorandum of the 14th instant,
I beg to say that the Department has paid a salary for the
teacher of the Shaguinandah R. C. Indian Day School from September
first, 1929.

It has been in continuous operation since that time, and
for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1934, there has been an enrol-
ment of 12 and an average of 7 pupils. During the same year, 16
children were enrolled at the Shaguinandah Protestant School, with
an average attendance of 9.

Following the recognition of the Shaguinandah R. C.
School in 1929, the Department received protests along practically
the same lines as are apparently contained in the communication
from your correspondent. In 1931, a department official was sent
to Shaguinandah to investigate the matter, and he reported as
follows:-

"When the Shaguinandah Reserve was established, it and
the Sucker Creek Reserve were supposed to be for the Prot-
estant Indians of that time. At Shaguinandah, particularly,
Catholic families have settled and it has been necessary to
make a decision concerning a separate school. Mr. L. F.
Hardyman, Church of England missionary there, has indicated
it was his understanding that the Catholic families should
not be allowed to settle on this reserve and he has some-
what bitterly opposed the establishment of a separate school.
I informed him that, whereas the reserve may have been
established for Protestant Indians 50 years ago, the Depart-
ment could not guarantee that the Indians living there would
remain Protestant. I also stated that Indians from other
reserves in the vicinity, whether Protestant or Catholic,
would not likely be prohibited from moving to Shaguinandah
provided they had an opportunity of bettering themselves
from an economic standpoint. It appears that, recently, the
Indians at South Bay have had a difficult time and they are
leaving there and are having somewhat better luck at
Shaguinandah.

"I made a careful examination of the nominal roll at
the R. C. School, interviewing both Mr. Hardyman and Father
Papineau, concerning each child, and, along with Agent Lewis
and Inspector McGeehan, visiting some of the homes, in an
effort to secure additional information. I learned that 7
of the children were clearly eligible for a Catholic school;
that 8 or 10 others might be considered importations to the
reserve and in the case of one or two additional, the religious affiliation was doubtful.

"Of the 10 that appear as if they might be import-
ations for the purpose of bolstering the claim for a separate school, 2 are living with their grandmother, a resident of the reserve, the parents being separated; 2 are living with an aunt, as their own home near Whitefish Falls was distant from the Indian school; 2, along with their mother, originally from Grassay Bay, are staying with a resident of the reserve; and 2 are living with an aunt who is looking after them, there being no school near their own home at South Bay. I am quite satisfied that Father Papineau is assisting with the board for these children.

"The fact remains that there are nearly 20 Roman Catholic children living on the Shagwandah Reserve and I take it that it is the Department's duty to educate them. In addition, there are 9 younger children who will be eligible from year to year."

No further protests were received about this school until December, 1883, when Mr. Agent Lewis forwarded a petition, signed by certain Indians, requesting that the Shagwandah R. C. School be closed in order to curtail school expenditure. In forwarding this document, the Agent stated that it had not been passed by the Shagwandah Band in Council but had been circulated through the reserve. He was advised, in reply, that the Department was not prepared to close the school.

The latest census of the Shagwandah Reserve shows a population of 106, of whom 65 are Anglicans and 40 Roman Catholics. There are 9 children under 7 years of age and 25 children from 7 to 16 years.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memo:

Referring to communication which you received from the Right Honourable the Prime Minister, with regard to the Indian school situation at Sheguianidah, Ont., I would say that, from time to time, since the establishment of the day school for the Catholic Indian children, protests, along practically the same lines as are apparently contained in the communication to the Prime Minister, have been made against continuing this school. These protests have been instigated, for the most part, by the Missionary of the Anglican Church. The Catholic day school was first opened in September, 1929, and has been in continuous operation since that time. At present, there is an enrolment of 10 pupils, with an average attendance of 8.

When the Sheguianidah reserve was established, it was for the Protestant Indians of that time. Catholic families have since settled on the reserve and a separate school was established. The Church of England Missionary has, from time to time, indicated it was his understanding that Catholic families should not be allowed to settle on this reserve, and he has somewhat bitterly opposed the establishment of a separate school. A departmental official, who investigated the matter in 1934, informed the Missionary that whereas the reserve may have been established for Protestant Indians 50 years ago, the Department could not guarantee that the Indians living there would remain Protestant, and it would be impossible to prohibit Catholic Indians from moving to Sheguianidah, where they would have an opportunity of bettering themselves from an economic standpoint.

The children of the Catholic Indians who moved to the reserve are considered by the Anglican Church authorities as importations to the reserve, in order that there will be sufficient children to carry on a Catholic school. Of the children that appear as if they might be importations for the purpose of bolstering the claim for a separate school, two are living with their grandmother, a resident of the reserve, the parents being separated; two are living with an aunt as their own home near Whitefish Falls was distant from an Indian school; two, along with their mother, originally from Grass Bay, are staying with a resident of the reserve; and two are living with an aunt, who is looking after them, there being no school near their own home at South Bay.

Paragraph 3, Section 100, of the Indian Act, sets forth that the Protestant or Catholic minority of any Band may, with the approval of, and under regulations made by the Governor in Council, have a separate school established on the reserve.

The complaints that are received from time to time against the conduct of a school for the Catholic children arise through local jealousy and, in the past, have been instigated by the missionaries of the Anglican Church.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the Sheguianah R.C. and Sheguianah C.E. Indian Day Schools.

In view of the information now before us, it has been decided to close both of these schools on June 30th, 1937 and you should so inform the teachers. Please let me know whether or not the teachers were successful in securing other schools. If not, the Department will endeavour to place them in Indian day schools but, at the present time, we are not in a position to definitely assure you that this can be done.

Indian Day School, I have the honour to report that the Indians at Sheguianah have been advised of the Department's decision in this matter.

The matter of having the Indian children attend the neighbouring White school in Sheguianah Township has been taken up with the School Board and at their meeting during the last week in June they gave this matter due consideration, but since this meeting they have found so many of the ratepayers opposed to Indian children attending the White school, and as it is there is a large enrollment of White pupils, they finally decided that they would not accept any Indian children and advised me by letter of the 15th instant accordingly.

As the Board of the White school have come to a decision that they will not accept Indian children, and there are not sufficient pupils of school age at Sheguianah to warrant the Department to continue two day schools, I would recommend that both schools remain closed, as advised by letter of June 10th, and all children of school age be placed in residential schools.

Ottawa, August 4, 1937.

Dear Mr. Farquhar:

I have, for acknowledgment, your letter of July 26th, in which you refer to the decision of the Department to close for the time being the Catholic Indian Day School at Shagwandah and in which you remind me that the Priest in charge of the Mission is opposed to this decision.

I may state, by way of explanation, that Dr. H. W. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs, visited this school during the early part of May, and, in reporting to the Honourable the Minister, stated:

"On our way to Manitouining, we called at the Shagwandah Reserve and visited the two schools - one under Roman Catholic auspices, being held in the church building. The teacher is Miss Lapointe and her total enrolment consists of six pupils. The Protestant School, under Miss Ballantyne, has an enrolment of five. Both these teachers seem to be capable and further enrolment seems to be unnecessary upon the fact that we maintain two schools and pay two teachers' salaries for a total enrolment of eleven pupils."

The Department subsequently communicated with Indian Agent Lewis, who supplied the following information in connection with the Shagwandah Church of England and Roman Catholic Schools:

"The Anglican School, under Miss Ballantyne as teacher, has an enrolment of five pupils. The prospect

Thomas Farquhar, Esq., M.P.,
Mindemoya,
Ontario,

Aug. 5/37"
prospect is that if the school re-opens after the summer holidays there will be an enrolment of not more than four pupils. Bridget Gaikeshayengai is over school age and will not return after the end of this school term."

"With regard to the school operated under Roman Catholic auspices, of which Miss A. C. Lapointe is teacher, this school had an enrolment of six pupils until this month. Now there are eight, as two children of Point Grondine Band are in attendance at the present time. There does not seem to be any prospect whatever of an increase in the attendance at this school during the academic year 1937-38. In fact, it would appear that the attendance would show a decrease if this school should continue in operation. My reason for believing this is as follows:

"William Gaikeshayengai, aged fifteen, in Grade 7 - attendance has been unsatisfactory for some time during the past. As he is now able to work, I believe that he will not continue after the close of the present term.

"Lawrence Misinishketwe, in Grade 7 - will attain the age of sixteen this coming Fall.

"Nadeline, Paul and Rose Nahwaikeshik, aged seven, nine and ten, respectively, children of Simon Nahwaikeshik - have not a permanent home at Shagwianish. At present, these children and their parents reside with their aged grandfather. It is a question whether, or not, this family will remain at Shagwianish for any length of time. The parents take little interest in the school and will send the children when forced to do so only."

After giving this matter careful consideration, it was decided to close both the Shagwianish Church of England and Roman Catholic Indian Day Schools on June 30th, 1937,
owing to the fact that the small attendance at both schools did not justify the expenditure. If it is found impossible to obtain accommodation for these Indian pupils in adjoining White schools, they will be placed in residential schools.

In view of these facts and in view of the fact that we have requests from districts in which there are large groups of Indian children for whom no educational facilities have been provided by the Department, I think you will agree with me that the Department was justified in closing both these schools, and I feel confident that the Priest in charge of the Mission will be satisfied with this explanation.

Yours sincerely,

Secretary.

Dear Mr. Nicholson:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the Sheguianah R. C. Indian Day School. A year ago this activity for the Roman Catholic children of the reserve was commenced classes being held in the church. It was the intention to provide a suitable building if the school proved successful. In November, when the Estimates for the current fiscal year were prepared, there were really no representations that it would be timely this year to consider the work permanent and to incur capital expenditure. In the late winter, when it was too late to secure funds, except for emergencies, the Reverend Father Papineau, S. J., commenced to press for a building. When he was satisfied that the Department had no funds for the purpose this year, he offered to be responsible for the building activity, provided the Department would reimburse him next year. This, of course, was not proceeding in the regular manner, and I felt that there would be no serious loss to the work if the new building was not ready until 1931.

This is still my opinion, and, as the school appears to be worth while, I propose to ask Parliament for funds at the next regular session.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the erection of the catholic school at Shegu iandah, I have to make the following suggestions:

1. We would finance the construction under your immediate supervision and follow absolutely all your specifications.

2. We will forward vouchers for every expenditure.

3. The Department would refund the money whenever convenient, in 3 or 4 years; and if the school is not a real success, we dispense the School's branch from remitting on a single cent.

4. We make this supplication because the White People, owners of the church in which the classes are taught, object to our using their building any further.

5. The construction would be done more economically, by day work directed by a competent foreman, as was done for the Birch Island school.

6. Chief William Widibins has donated an excellent lot in the most central place.

7. To make the cellar warmer in Winter and cooler in Summer we would ask for a stone foundation instead of cement.

8. To save the expense of a wood shed, we would ask to make the cellar full size of the building for storing fuel, wood.

9. To save per petual expensive outside painting, we would ask to use guaranteed Stuco put on by an expert.

Honorable and Dear Mr. Murphy:

Further to discussion I had with you last week regarding Indian Day School at Sheguiandah,

The situation is as I pointed out; namely, that the Roman Catholic day school is being carried on in the church just outside of the reserve. The church is not large, is unsuitable for school purposes, as I am confident your inspectors will advise you, and the "nite population in the district who have built and own the church and who worship there regularly feel that it should not be used for that purpose. They are also of opinion to support their view which I need not discuss here. The Missionary Priest in charge at Sheguiandah and the Bishop of the diocese, His Lordship Bishop Scollard, each recognize the difficulties that your Department is faced with in meeting the demands made upon it under present conditions, and with that in mind they are prepared to build the school with their own funds or credit, providing your department will give them a letter to the effect that the money would be granted to them just as soon as you were in a position to make grants for purposes of that character. They will follow strictly plans and specifications that the Department may make and keep strictly within the limits of whatever expenditure the Department sets and I would urge that their proposal in this regard be accepted, and that they be authorised to go ahead this year. It will assist in a small way in the relief of unemployment. The school can be built much more economically than under ordinary conditions. An unsatisfactory condition will be rectified and the interests of the Department adequately protected.

Will you kindly give this your favorable consideration?

Yours very truly,

G. B. Nicholson,

Sir—

I have the honour to enclose herewith a requisition by Mr. W.D. Murray for a few articles for use at the Shogrimash School.

There are only two drinking cups on hand at present so 10 new ones are required in order that each pupil should have an individual cup. The tooth brushes are all worn out and should be replaced by 12 new brushes.

The pupils attending this school have been taking their midday meal at home; therefore, hot cocoa has not been served so far this winter. It is thought that if the Department could authorize a small supply of cocoa, sugar and milk to the extent of $5.00 per month a hot drink would be served to each pupil in the forenoon each day which would be beneficial to the children's health.

Ottawa, February 13, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Sheguindah R. C. Day School and requesting that a grant be allowed for the purchase of supplies for the purpose of serving a hot drink to the pupils.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of ten drinking cups; also for a small supply of cocoa, sugar and milk, to an amount not exceeding the sum of $3.00 per month, for the period from the middle of the present month to the middle of April, next, viz., two months. You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Twelve tooth brushes will be sent the teacher from here.

An order will be forwarded the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the number of drawings to colour considered necessary.

MONTHLY REPORT

Sturgeon Falls Indian Agency.

A meeting of the Whitefish Lake Indians was held at Lake Penache on August 27th re proposed building of school house at Lake Penache. Mr. Brunne has offered to supply the material and the Indians will supply the labour free. The building to be supervised by Mr. Brunne. OTTAWA, 19th November, 1902

The Secretary:

Mr Agent Thorburn forwards a resolution from the Cockburn Island Band asking the Department to establish a school for their children on the reserve and to provide the salary for a teacher.

The Indian population of the Island is given as 56 with about 14 or 15 children of school age and they are all Roman Catholics.

They have had no school on the Island for a number of years but applications have been received from time to time since '95 for one. In that year the Department consented to pay a salary of $200.00 for a qualified teacher on condition that an average attendance of 8 pupils could be maintained. Apparently they were unable to obtain a teacher for that salary and the school was not opened. In '99 Father Artus, who was then Superintendent of Missions, again applied for a school, when he was told that there was no money available and that the funds of the Band could not bear a charge for a teacher's salary.

If the Department agrees to the request of the Indians being granted, funds will have to be provided in the estimates for a teacher's salary.

There is an old church building on the Island which with an expenditure of $125.00, could be adapted for school purposes and the Indians are willing to have this amount taken from the capital funds of their Band.

The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

By this time, your office will be flooded with literature from the Cockburn Island Reserve—may I take, in the name of your evident zeal for the Indians' welfare, a few moments of your time to explain the cause of the quarrel—

As soon as the Cockburn Island Reserve school was started, a certain hunchback named John Avis (who a few years ago spent six months in the Gore Bay Jail, for bribery and half killing his mother) began to agitate to get the position of teacher in that new school—upon being told that as he was a Protestant, he could not teach those Catholic Indians, he determined to have those Catholic Indians turn Protestant so that he might become their teacher—

It is perfectly well known to you that the little Catholic Band of Cockburn Island has lived in great peace since twenty years
John Avis started a campaign of slander against the Catholic Church and schools. Often went on the Cockburn Reserve, conversed, coaxed the Indians to become Protestant, and soon gained to his cause: Jonas Akibinossie and Edward Segars and chief Joseph Wagot. Jonas Akibinossie has lived in public illegal concubinage during the last fifteen years with two different women, having rejected his own lawful wife, and never come to church. Ed. Segar is not a concubine but never goes to church—With these two scandalous helpers, John Avis made strenuous efforts to create a division in the band. I enclose a letter which he wrote to Father Richards, last February, and by which you will judge this disturbing jail bird.

At last he succeeded in calling on the Reserve, two Anglican Ministers. They went there Sunday May 9th. By a thousand alluring promises they deceived those quiet ignorant Indians; they created an Anglican clan—they told them that if they turned Anglicans they would become rich and happy, they would receive lots of clothing and food and that their old people would be fed gratis—etc etc—They made a petition.
On Monday May 10th P.M. I arrived there in company of Mr. Baxter and Dr. Baker. I discovered the division at once upon hearing incognito some of the quarrels between Catholics and Protestants.

The chief and his two helpers Jonas Akabinose & Ed Logan were swearing that they would never allow a Catholic teacher to come on the Reserve. As this Rachel Malton was to arrive that same evening I told Mr. Baxter that he should impose his authority, reduce the agitators to silence and give me the keys of the school. He was quite frightened by the Indians and did not dare ask the keys from the chief. He left me there in charge and told me to introduce the teacher in the school. The next day the chief refused to open the school and to give the keys to the teacher. I called Mr. Baxter on the phone to warn him. He sent by constable Stewart, a summons to chief Joe Wapogah, ordering him to give the keys and authorized me to open the school in spite of the chief in case of refusal. Constable Stewart drove to the Reserve and read the summons to the chief who encouraged and prompted by the two agitators, bluntly...
refused to give the keys. I then boldly and sternly told the chief that I was going to open the school with my own keys and this I did in the presence of all the Indians, and I introduced the teacher on the school Tuesday May 11th at 5 o'clock.

The Indians were quite afraid of me and I imposed myself. At that time, ten families were sorry for their mistake and had come back to their old catholic church. On Wednesday morning the ten catholic families sent their fifteen children to school and declared themselves delighted with the teacher — on Wednesday P.M. John Lewis came on the Reserve, held a consultation with the three agitators, and came with them near the school to intimidate the teacher. I chased them all from around the school. As a result of the visit of John Lewis, the three agitators declared about the village that as soon as I would be gone, they would throw stones at the windows and chase the teacher away. I wrote all these details to Mr. Baxter, and requested him, in his honor, to protect that teacher.
hired and sent there on his authorization—

"The three agitators repeated all the time that before leaving, Monday May 10th Mr. Baxter would have told them privately those extremely grievous words 'The school is yours you may do with it what you like'."

It is upon these words that they based their refusal to give the keys.

Considering that one of the wisest and most clever measures passed by your Department, is the most absolute control of all Indian schools by your Department without the least interfering of any chief or any Reserve, these words if they have been said would constitute a disastrous treason of the Department's authority over the Indians, and place a still worst sentiment in the hearts of the Indians—You may well imagine the awful fright of Miss Allen when I leave. Dear Sir,

I just returned from the Indian village, Cockburn Island, and I find your letter of May 11th No. 163101/1. In answer, I beg most humbly for your indulgence, because I have perhaps contributed to embarrass you — On May 7th, Mr. Baxter, Agent of the Cockburn Reserve, told me that the question of a teacher was causing great disturbance on that last Reserve and that a teacher should be sent to Cockburn without the least delay. I told him since a week I had referred the matter to you for a choice between four candidates, but that I had no answer. Thinking that you might be exceptionally busy at this present time, he (Mr. Baxter) presumed your permission, and told me to send at once,
one of the four applicants, to the Rockburn Reserve school, because he feared that a delay might cause bloodshed between the two groups of Indians, quarrelling about an Anglican or a Catholic teacher. — Judging by the length of teaching experience and more local disposition, with the recommendation of Rev. Father Richard who knew all applicants, we sent word, on Friday, to Miss Rachel Maller to take charge of the Rockburn Reserve school. — I made a special trip to Rockburn Island, to introduce her. She came on Monday 10th. After extreme difficulty, which I narrate in the accompanying memoir, I introduced Miss Rachel Maller in the school, Tuesday P.M. I remained with her Wednesday and Thursday to make her acquainted with her fifteen pupils, and to interpret for her to those pupils of whom many do not understand a word of English — Your appointment of Miss McLean, place Mr. Baxter & myself in great embarrassment and I feel awfully sorry to have unintentionally countenanced your views. Of course
Mr. Baxter has the official responsibility of the measure taken, but you are always so good to us in all school affairs, that I regret immensely this annoying misunderstanding. Have you, by this time, cancelled Miss McLeary's engagement? If useful I am most willing to humiliate myself and apologize to the hurted parties.

Re the garden, Ex chief George Wagon has offered me a strip of his farm for the school garden—I will make another trip there and try to arrange things according to your least desires—

Most gratefully Yours

[Signature]

Little Current

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott—

Re: religious difficulty in connection with Cockburn Island School.

Mr. Agent Baxter wired the Department on the 11th instant that the majority of the Cockburn Island Indians had turned Protestant and refused to allow a Roman Catholic teacher to take charge of their school. Father Papineau sent a night lettergram on the 12th instant, in which he stated that against the will of the majority of the Indians Chief Joseph Wegosh refused to accept Miss Rachael Mallan, who was sent by Agent Baxter to teach this school, but that he had induced her to remain on.

Yesterday two letters were received from Father Papineau about the difficulty there, from which it would appear that the Indians there were insistent in having their school re-opened and to meet their demands Mr. Agent Baxter sent Miss Mallan without waiting for the authority of the Department.

A number of applications were received for this position and Miss McLarney was selected and advised of her appointment.
appointment and requested to take charge of the school as soon as possible. Miss Mallan is at present in charge and, owing to Mr. Baxter's unauthorized action, the Department has two teachers on its hands, neither of whom is acceptable to the Indians, if Mr. Baxter's telegram is correct.

Father Papineau sends in a memorial signed by twelve Indian heads of families on the reserve, in which they set forth that they signed the petition asking for a Protestant teacher under misrepresentations. As the population total of this band is only fifty-six, twenty of whom are under twenty-one years of age, the memorial sent in by Father Papineau must contain a large majority of the names of the voting members of the band.

Miss Mallan is in charge of this school with an enrolment of fifteen pupils and, as her appointment is satisfactory to the Roman Catholic church authorities, I would suggest that she be allowed to remain until the religious question is decided. Dear Kind Sir,

Concerning teacher for the Cockburn Island Indian school, I wrote to you on the 15th instant.

I am on my way to Cockburn Reserve and will be glad to see that the pupils begin their little gardens. George Wagoosh has donated the land but it is not fenced in. What are we to do about it?

With reference to gardening, let me quote, in ending, a little incident of the present religious quarrel at Cockburn. Peter Tekoma, who married a daughter of Hyacinthe Wagoosh, raised a numerous family during nearly 20 years; has done more clearing on the reserve than all the other Indians together. Now because he is as good a Catholic as he is an active worker, the three agitators have succeeded in obtaining a vote to expel him from the Reserve.

Respectfully Yours,

Father Papelean,

Dear Sir,

I have your kind letter of May 25th — No. 163101/1

In reply I beg to state that I cannot have been misunderstood. Miss Meller has not been forced to leave the school.

When she arrived to open the school, with the full authorization of Mr. Agent Baxter, Chief Joseph Wagon refused to give her the keys. Mr. Agent Baxter then authorized me officially to open the school and introduce the teacher. This I did, and since two weeks, the school has been going steadily, with an average attendance of thirteen children. Last week, we have laid out twelve plots for a school garden and...
the seeds which you authorized me to secure are being put in.

Everybody is fairly reconciled with state of things, and the attendant children are so eager to learn that it would be great damage to education in the Indian village if teaching was now interrupted. Miss Maller being sick for the present, our Agent Baxter has authorized Miss Fuzzy Fox to take her place.

I supplicate you very earnestly to reconsider the matter and to allow the school to go on until July—my object in writing to you on the 14th last was to explain the origin of the agitation in order that your Department might stop the agitators.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Sir:

I herewith enclose a correct statement of the Attendance Report of the Cockburn Island Indian School. I taught up to May 28th, and after I had sent in my resignation, and left there, I was informed that you had closed the school.

In regard to the way business is carried on there, I think you should know the truth. The Indians there are allowed to run the school. The Chief there refused to give up the keys to the Agent. He also nailed up a notice on the School door, forbidding any person to enter. When I went there I was given to understand that I was the appointed teacher, and the doors were opened for me to enter, the keys still being in the Chief's possession. Father Papineau was there during this time.

I felt more than nervous going to such a place and at such a time, and especially when I heard that the Agent had told the Indians that that was their school. This statement of course
encouraged them and placed me a young girl, without any protection, in a dangerous position. It is no place for a white person to go to, much less an unprotected girl, and for all I had to put up with during my stay there, I feel I should be recompensed. I am sending you the Register, and hope it is alright.

Yours respectfully,

Rachel Mullen

My dear Sir,

Certain Indians of Cockburn Island with their families have signified to me their intention to sever all connection with the Roman Catholic Church, and to seek admission to the Anglican Communion.

I have replied expressing my reluctance to interfere with Indians who are under Roman Catholic supervision and bidding them think well and carefully over the step they propose to take. I have also sent to them a deputation of two to look into the matter on the spot and urge the consideration of their decision.

These representatives, being the Rev. B. P. Fuller of the Shingwauk Home and the
Rev. S. H. Ferris of Garden River, have reported to me that they believe the chief cause of dissatisfaction among these Indians to be the lack of a good school, and possibly some little friction with the Roman Catholic authorities. They are convinced that the trouble is serious, and that the Indians are quite insistent in their purpose of leaving the Roman Communion.

I now write to lay the matter before you, and to express my willingness to do what I can for these people if they are in earnest and persistent in their purpose.

You will probably wish to inquire into the matter before committing the Department to any action. This would not doubt be wise. It is much to be desired that the whole band should agree as to the course to be pursued. There is no room for two voices; you are too smart...
I shall be glad to have your advice and judgment on the matter at the earliest possible date.

Believe me

Most faithfully yours

George A.

P.S. Enclosed you will find a copy of the documents sent me by the Indians referred to above.

In view of the fact that expenditure has been incurred in establishing the school and the teacher there on the ground, I would recommend that the Roman Catholic school be continued for this season at least. Some of the Indians expressed a wish to me that the school should be kept open during the summer holidays and until November, and closed during the winter; this suggestion I would commend for your approval. The teacher is continuing the work subject to instructions through the agent. By the end of this season the situation may be clearer and some satisfactory
solution arrived at.

It will be seen if Saibumosai's two girls are admitted to the Shingwauk, which I presume they will when he has satisfied the Department as to his religious beliefs, there will not be sufficient Protestant children to warrant the establishment of a second school. In that event, I think the Protestants should take advantage of the facilities afforded by the Shingwauk Home.

Some consideration had been given to a suggestion that this band should abandon their present location and take up on adjoining the Sheshegwaning Reserve. I have obtained information with regard to the lands there, which will be submitted to you in due course. Sir,

In connection with previous correspondence relative to school matters on Cockburn Island I beg to say that, as the result of the investigation made by Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, it has been decided that the school conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church on the island shall be continued for this season at least and, as some of the Indians have expressed a wish that the school should be kept open during the summer holidays until November and closed during the winter, this may be done. It is hoped that you will be able to secure the attendance of all of the children of school age on the island.

Should any of the Protestant parents object to sending their children to this school they can be sent to the Shingwauk Home.

I have to request that you will inform the Indians of the tenor of this letter.

Secretary of Indian Schools,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa -

Gentlemen:

I mentioned to you on my last letter, that I had given a list of articles, which I required for the house, to the agent, Mr. Baxter.

I have thought the matter over, and have concluded that owing to the fact that the department has decided to move the Cockburn Island Indians to Sheshegunning, they would not like to make any more expenses than are really necessary.

I would like to say that there are a few things, which I am certainly in need of, and you will please find enclosed a list of same.

Father Papineau is very kind and deprived himself of a lot of things he has in the church, to accommodate me.
I've had his bedding in use all last year, and I had to take possession of it again this year. I dare say that I have his sheets and pillow cases nearly worn out.

The wood should be cut as soon as possible, so that it would have time to dry, and at present I only have a few sticks of kindling wood on hand.

If you will give me the authority I will arrange with the Indians to have the wood cut.

The articles mentioned, I could purchase myself, have them charged and send you in the bill, then you could refund me the money.

Will inform you as soon as receive the desks, stationery etc.

You will greatly oblige me by granting me those articles mentioned. I will try and satisfy myself with the rest.

Thinking you for past favors, and trusting to have a favorable reply I beg to remain

Your humble servant,

Susie A. Jeff

(Teacher)
The Cockburn Island school was in session at the time of my visit, six pupils being present. Miss Fex is bright and is interested in her work but has much to contend with. She was out of chalk and only a few days previous to my visit had received a box which she had a friend send to her.

The improvements put on the schoolhouse last year have made it fairly comfortable but a few things might be supplied which would make the teacher more comfortable. The stove should be moved out to the shed but to do this the roof of the shed requires mending and to do this a strip of roofing 17 feet long is necessary. This could be put on by one of the Indians. A shanty roof cap for the stove pipe to pass through and a square of tin 3' x 3' should be provided for back of the stove and I would recommend that the Agent be authorized to have these done at once.

As the Cockburn Island Indians have decided not to move it may be necessary to keep the school going. If this is decided by the Department I would suggest that the following articles requested by Miss Fex be provided.

- 5 cords of hardwood and 1 cord cedar
- 2 hoses
- 1 sprinkler
- 1 pair of feather pillows

Sir,

2nd August 1925.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

On my recent visit to the Anglican Indian Day School at Sheeshgwening, I was asked by the band to request you to arrange for the reopening of this school, which has now been closed for about five years.

Two other children have recently come into the Reserve, who have been up to the present studying in the Central School, Sault Ste. Marie, under the name of Cadotte. As the father has deserted the mother, she has reverted to the name of Sampson. I have seen these children, and they are quite intelligent, and really ought to have an opportunity of continuing their education.

There are now six children on the Reserve for whom a school is required, namely, - Stanley Naniginiwina, aged 15, Angus Cada, aged 13, Guy Sampson, 14, Nancy Cada, 10, Lloyd Sampson, 11, and Louis Sampson, 8.

The school seemed to be in good condition, and I should be very glad to receive authorization from you to nominate a teacher.

With all best wishes,

Yours very sincerely,

+ Rocksborough R. Algoma
Ottawa, August 9, 1935.

Right Rev. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 2nd instant, I beg to say that, owing to lack of funds, the Department is unable to consider reopening the Sheshegwaning C. E. Indian Day School this year.

Three of the children mentioned in your letter appear eligible for admission to the Shingwauk Home, where, as you know, there is plenty of accommodation. If they are medically fit and otherwise eligible, I feel certain the Indian Agent will be prepared to arrange for sending them. I am writing to him in the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Right Rev. R. R. Smith, Bishop of Algoma, requesting the reopening of the Sheshegwaning C. E. Indian Day School. He is being informed that, owing to lack of funds, the Department is not prepared to consider the matter at the present time.

He mentions in his letter Stanley Neniginiwina, Angus Gada, Guy Sampson, Nanoy Gada, Lloyd Sampson and Louis Sampson. If these children are Protestants, and in good health, the Department is prepared to consider approving their admission to the Shingwauk Home, where there is plenty of accommodation. In the event of any or all of these children wishing to go to Shingwauk Home, the usual application forms and certificates of health should be forwarded for the Department's consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

With reference to official letter 12-2-1 Aug.9th last regarding reopening of Protestant School at Sheshegwaning, I beg to advise that of the list of names given only two are members of the Sheshegwaning Band, Stanley Negawinina or Owl is an illegitimate child of Mary Negawinina and the Sampson children are enfranchised Indians or half breeds and do not live on the reserve but just outside the reserve and have been attending a white school the past few years.

I am sending admission forms to Paul Cada the father of the Cada children; these children attended Shingwauk about two years ago but as there was a sister in the family who had gone to High school she undertook to educate the younger children and got some assistance from the Inspector with math lessons by mail; they also were living off the reserve for a year or two but are back on the reserve now.

Sheshegwaning Band Minutes of Council Meeting held Nov.14,1938

No. 8.

Moved by Paul Cada, Sr., second by Matthew Sampson, that the department be requested to reopen the Anglican school at Sheshegwaning.

Motion eight, that the Department be requested to re-open the Anglican Indian Day School at Sheshegwaning Reserve. At present there are only six children of the Anglican Church faith living on the reserve, with ages ranging from 6 to 13 years. The R.C. school has an enrolment of twenty pupils. The total number of children living on the reserve of school age does not exceed 26. It would appear the one school is sufficient to accommodate all pupils of school age living on the reserve. Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Superintendent of Indian Agency,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Mr. Walkom's report dated March 18th, covering the Garden River C.E. Indian Day School has now been received. Under the "General Comment" column he mentions the following:

"There are fewer repeating this year and possibly Mr. Smith has somewhat better knowledge of pupil records. Two are repeating grade 1, 2; grade 11. None other is repeating the present year, though some have previously repeated. Progress in reading, though largely word-saying in junior grades, is fair; in arithmetic fair to good. Pupils continue to speak in a natural, audible voice, something apparently unusual in Indian schools.

Temperature at 9.30 was 50, at 10.15 64, and 11.45 80 degrees. Apparently the teacher has difficulty managing the fire. Classroom could be much tidier. It was suggested that work books, which are not neat and which show great waste, should be greatly improved. This was suggested last year too.

One was glad to see pupils supplied with cod liver oil, good soup made from stock and biscuits. One hopes for better regulated temperature, cleaner and tidier classroom, better work books and a somewhat more comprehensive understanding of the curriculum. Very creditable hand work is being done."
You will recall that I was somewhat critical also of the tidiness of this room. It is recommended that you draw this matter to Mr. Smith's attention and particularly draw his attention to the use of workbooks supplied by the Department. You might mention at an opportune time to Mr. Walkom that you have brought this matter to Mr. Smith's attention.

I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that we are considering the transfer of Mr. Smith from this school. We will probably be writing to him concerning this transfer. A copy of such correspondence will naturally be sent to you.

Bernard V. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. ST. LOUIS,
RECORDS DIVISION.

Sheheshwaning C.E. Day School.

The above Indian Day School has been closed for some years. I could not ascertain on my recent visit to this school the date when it was built. I would guess about 1912.

It is now very dilapidated and has been vandalised by Indian boys. I have recommended to Mr. Indian Superintendent Johnston that we turn it over to the local Indians for use as a council hall. In this way we could ensure that at least some care will be taken of it. It will never be operated as a school again unless conditions change radically.

Would you please ascertain from the old files as to ownership of this building. Apparently the Indians claim that a certain amount of Band Funds went into its construction.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
June 5, 1948.

Mr. C. H. Johnston,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

Sheshegwaning C.E., Indian Day School.

You will recall our recent conversation with regard to the Sheshegwaning Anglican Day School. On reference to our back files we find that this school was built in 1916. We also find that the amount required for the erection of this school was obtained from Band Funds. The original Order-in-Council reads as follows:

"The Minister recommends, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2, of section 36, of the Public Works Act, that the contract for the erection of the above mentioned building be awarded to George Stevin, the lowest tenderer, for the amount of his tender as above cited, namely, $3652.00; the same to be charged under the provisions of section 89 of the Indian Act, to the capital at the credit of the Sheshegwaning band, which amounts to $63,108.66."

Therefore, it will be necessary for you to refer this matter to the Sheshegwaning Band before a decision can be reached as to its use as a council hall.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

GORD BAY

TEACHERS RESIDENCE

SHESHEGWANING C. OF E. DAY SCHOOL
Bishophurst,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
August 18th, 1926

Dear Mr. McLean:

I wrote you on the 13th instant informing you that the Minister of Education agrees to accept Mr. Trowbridge's work in the Sheshegwaning Indian School as fulfilment of his obligation to the Department, and asking you for his formal appointment to that school.

Mr. Weeks who is removing from the School tells me that your Department usually provides a few articles of furniture for a single man like Mr. Trowbridge. It will be a very great help indeed to the young man if he may count upon a few necessary articles. I am sending this request in detail through Mr. McGregor the local Indian Agent. I simply acquaint you with it, hoping that in your reply about Mr. Trowbridge's appointment you will be able to tell me whether or no he may count upon this furniture.

With best wishes,

Believe me,

Faithfully yours,

George Thomeloe
Bishop & Stigma

J. D. McLean Esq.
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dept. Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

Gore Bay,

August 18th 1925.

Sir,

referring to your letter of 17th instant re Mr. Trowbridge taking the Ang. School, Sheshawanganing I beg to advise that His Grace, The Archbishop asks that stove, table, chairs, bedroom suite, oilcloth for floors, &c., be supplied. There has never been any furniture, dishes &c., supplied this school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 23, 1926.

Most Reverend Sir:

I have Your Grace's letter of the 18th instant, relative to the providing of a few articles of furniture for Mr. Trowbridge, who has been appointed teacher of the Sheshgwaning Anglican Indian Day School for the next academic year. We are taking this matter up with Mr. Agent McGregor, requesting him to ascertain from Mr. Trowbridge what is required. Consideration will then be given to authorizing the purchase. In official letter of the 17th instant, Your Grace was informed of the approval of Mr. Trowbridge's appointment.

I have the honour to be,

Most Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Most Rev. G. Thornloe, D.D.,
Archbishop of Algoma,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.
Ottawa, August 23, 1926.

Sir:

His Grace the Bishop of Algoma informs the Department that a few articles of furniture will be required by Mr. Trowbridge, who has been appointed teacher of the Sheshegwaning Anglican Indian Day School, in fitting up his living quarters. When Mr. Trowbridge arrives, you should consult him in the matter and inform the Department as to what is required. You should state only those furnishings which you consider are absolutely necessary. Please indicate the approximate cost of supplying them. This matter should receive your prompt attention after Mr. Trowbridge arrives to take up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. R. McGregor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gore Bay,
Ont.
Bishophurst,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
August 26th, 1926

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Dept Indian Affairs.
Ottawa. Ont.

Dear Sir:

I have received and thank you for your letter of
the 23rd instant no 12-2-5. I will inform Mr. Trowbridge
of the steps you are taking with regard to the furnishing

I have already sent him word that his appointment has been

Again thanking you for your kindness and courtesy.

Very sincerely yours,

George Dornelas
Bishop

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 23rd instant re furniture &c., for Sheshgwaning Ang. School I beg to advise that Mr. Trewbridge called on me today and asks for the following:

Bed, Dresser & W. Stand, Springs, Mattress, 2 bed sheets and 2 pair Pillow cases (He will furnish the bedding) Eaton's Price $55.20 Toilet sett $2.70

Cook stove $28.75.

Cooking utensils & dishes $15.00

6 blinds - $4.20

1 kitchen table & 3 chairs $8.65

Pails, wash dish, Dipper &c.$3.00

This does not allow for any furniture for a sitting room.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

[Handwritten note:]
Never anything done for free before.
Ottawa, September 2nd, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, giving a list of the furnishings required for the teacher's living quarters at the Sheshogwaning Indian Day School, and the cost of supplying same.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of a bed, complete with springs and mattress, also 2 pairs sheets, 2 pairs pillow cases, a toilet set and dresser and a cook stove. You may also purchase cooking utensils and dishes, the cost of which should not exceed the sum of $25. You may also purchase 6 window blinds, 1 kitchen table, 3 chairs, 2 water pails and 1 dipper. You should obtain competitive prices, if possible, for the supplying of the above furnishings and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. While serviceable articles should be obtained, it is not intended that any large expenditure be incurred, and the cost should be kept down to the lowest possible point. The purchase of these supplies should receive your immediate attention.

Please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of these supplies.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. R. McGregor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gore Bay, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your order and remittance of £104.74 have been received for which we thank you.

Goods valued at £28.69 were shipped on September 10 by C. P. R. freight via Owen Sound and Boat, and the balance of the order valued at £76.05 will go forward direct from the factory. The bill of lading will be mailed to you when the shipment is made. The bills are enclosed for your information.

Yours truly,

The T. Eaton Co. Limited.
